{"uri": "8115855599", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "15:37:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T15:37:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T15:37:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.inewsguyana.com/guyana-expresses-solidarity-with-brazil-following-devastating-floods/", "title": "Guyana expresses solidarity with Brazil following devastating floods", "body": "In the wake of devastating floods in Southern Brazil that have claimed the lives of over 80 and displaced over 120,000, President Dr. Irfaan Ali has extended a message of solidarity and sympathy to Guyana's neighbor to the south.\n\nIn an official letter to Brazilian President Luis Inacio Lula da Silva, President Ali noted that Guyana stood behind Brazil in its time of need and that the country was deeply saddened at the loss of lives and the devastation wrought by the severe flooding.\n\n\"On behalf of the Government and people of the Co-operative Republic of Guyana, I wish to convey profound sympathy to the Government and people of Brazil in the wake of the recent heavy rainfall and flooding which occurred in the State of Rio Grande do Sul.\"\n\n\"We are deeply saddened at the news of the loss of lives, the displacement of people and the widespread destruction caused by severe flooding in that region,\" President Ali conveyed in the letter.\n\nExpressing solidarity with the people of Brazil, who in addition to the official death toll are still to account for hundreds of people who are currently missing, President Ali paid tribute to the resilient spirit of the Brazilian people.\n\n\"I therefore, wish to express solidarity with the people of Brazil during this difficult time. I am confident that the determined and resilient spirit of the Brazilian people will triumph over this unfortunate tragedy. Please accept, excellency, the assurances of my highest consideration,\" President Ali added.\n\nThere have been a series of floods in the Rio Grande do Sul state, leaving 276 persons injured, 111 missing and 121,000 displaced. These statistics were provided by the Civil Defense agency in the state on Monday.\n\nAdditionally, over 850,000 persons in 345 municipalities were affected by the disaster, which also destroyed homes and infrastructure such as roads and bridges. As a matter of fact, over 60 roads have either been totally or partially blocked because of the flooding.\n\nIn addition, the Gua\u00edba River water level rose again on Sunday morning to 5.33 centimeters, making it the highest water level in history. Waters from this river have flooded the historic center of the regional capital of Porto Alegre, a city of 1.3 million inhabitants.\n\nThen there is also the city's international airport, which was closed on Friday night as the flood had reached its runways. According to reports from out of Rio Grande do Sul, the airport remains closed.\n\nThe Brazilian President had also visited Rio Grande do Sul on Sunday to survey the affected areas and oversee the emergency response efforts. During his visit, the head of state made it clear that all levels of government have been mobilised to work together during the emergency.\n\n\"I am a man who believes very much in God. And I put my team of ministers at the disposal of this journey. I also called the representatives of the other powers. It was necessary to see closely, as we are doing here, to understand the scale of what happened and to help the population of the South,\" Lula said afterwards.", "source": {"uri": "inewsguyana.com", {"uri": "8112640317", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "17:44:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T17:44:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T17:44:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/world/americas/2024-05-05-death-toll-rises-after-floods-in-brazil/", "title": "Death toll rises after floods in Brazil", "body": "Porto Alegre/Canoas -- The death toll from heavy rains that have caused flooding in Brazil's southern state of Rio Grande do Sul has risen to at least 75, local authorities said on Sunday, with tens of thousands of people displaced.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva arrived in Rio Grande do Sul on Sunday, along with most members of his cabinet, to discuss rescue and reconstruction works with local authorities.\n\nThe death toll could still substantially increase as 103 people were reported missing on Sunday, up from about 70 the day before, according to the state civil defence authority. It also said it was investigating whether another six deaths were related to the storms.\n\nIt was raining on Sunday morning in Porto Alegre, the capital of Rio Grande do Sul, and in other parts of the state, which could make rescue efforts even harder. Flooding from storms in the past few days has affected about two thirds of the nearly 500 towns and cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina, leaving more than 88,000 displaced.\n\nFloods have destroyed roads and bridges in several cities. The rains also have triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the Guaiba lake broke its banks by more than 2m , hitting the highest water level on records, according to the national geological service. Porto Alegre's international airport has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nState governor Eduardo Leite told reporters on Saturday evening that Rio Grande do Sul would need a \"Marshall Plan\" to recover from the storms and its consequences, referring to the US-led plan for Europe's economic recovery after World War 2.\n\nIn the city of Canoas, near Porto Alegre, Julio Manichesque, 76, was rescued by volunteers after he had stayed since Friday on the roof of the house where he has lived for 52 years.\n\n\"I have never seen that much water,\" Manichesque said.\n\nDuring his weekly address to crowds in St Peter's Square in Vatican City, Pope Francis said on Sunday he was praying for the people of the state.\n\n\"I assure my prayers for the people of the state of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil, affected by major floods. May the Lord receive the dead, comfort their families and all those who had to leave their homes,\" the pope said.", "source": {"uri": "businesslive.co.za", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8112556806", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:18:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:18:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:16:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2928366-death-toll-from-southern-brazil-rainfall-rises-to-75-many-still-missing", "title": "Death toll from southern Brazil rainfall rises to 75, many still missing | Science-Environment", "body": "It also said it was investigating whether another six deaths were related to the storms. It was raining on Sunday morning in Porto Alegre, the capital of Rio Grande do Sul, and in other parts of the state, which could make rescue efforts even harder.\n\nThe death toll from heavy rains that have caused flooding in Brazil's southern state of Rio Grande do Sul has risen to at least 75, local authorities said on Sunday, with tens of thousands of people displaced.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva arrived in Rio Grande do Sul on Sunday, along with most members of his cabinet, to discuss rescue and reconstruction works with local authorities. The death toll could still substantially increase as 103 people were reported missing on Sunday, up from about 70 the prior day, according to the state civil defense authority. It also said it was investigating whether another six deaths were related to the storms.\n\nIt was raining on Sunday morning in Porto Alegre, the capital of Rio Grande do Sul, and in other parts of the state, which could make rescue efforts even harder. Flooding from storms in the past few days has affected about two thirds of the nearly 500 towns and cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina, leaving more than 88,000 displaced. Floods have destroyed roads and bridges in several cities. The rains also have triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the Guaiba lake broke its banks by more than two meters (7 feet), hitting the highest water level on records, according to the national geological service. Porto Alegre's international airport has suspended all flights since Friday. State Governor Eduardo Leite told reporters on Saturday evening that Rio Grande do Sul would need a \"Marshall Plan\" to recover from the storms and its consequences, referring to the U.S.-led plan for Europe's economic recovery after World War Two.\n\nIn the city of Canoas, near Porto Alegre, Julio Manichesque, 76, was rescued by volunteers after he had stayed since Friday on the roof of the house where he has lived for 52 years. \"I have never seen that much water,\" Manichesque said.\n\nDuring his weekly address to crowds in St. Peter's Square in Vatican City, Pope Francis said on Sunday he was praying for the people of the state. \"I assure my prayers for the people of the state of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil, affected by major floods. May the Lord receive the dead, comfort their families and all those who had to leave their homes,\" the pope said.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a Reuters\n\nThe death toll from heavy rains that have caused flooding in Brazil's southern state of Rio Grande do Sul has risen to at least 78, local authorities said on Sunday, with more than 115,000 people displaced.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva arrived in Rio Grande do Sul on Sunday morning with most members of his cabinet to discuss rescue and reconstruction efforts with local authorities.\n\n\"Bureaucracy will not stand in our way, stopping us from recovering the state's greatness,\" Lula said at a press conference.\n\n\"It is a war scenario, and will need post-war measures,\" state governor Eduardo Leite added.\n\nVolunteers using boats, jet skis - and even swimming - have assisted in ongoing rescue efforts. {"uri": "8112792204", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "20:47:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T20:47:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T20:46:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.ntd.com/death-toll-from-southern-brazil-rainfall-rises-to-75-over-100-still-missing_990772.html", "title": "Death Toll From Southern Brazil Rainfall Rises to 75, Over 100 Still Missing", "body": "PORTO ALEGRE/CANOAS -- The death toll from heavy rains that have caused flooding in Brazil's southern state of Rio Grande do Sul has risen to at least 75, local authorities said on Sunday, with tens of thousands of people displaced.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva arrived in Rio Grande do Sul on Sunday, along with most members of his cabinet, to discuss rescue and reconstruction works with local authorities.\n\nThe death toll could still substantially increase as 103 people were reported missing on Sunday, up from about 70 the prior day, according to the state civil defense authority. It also said it was investigating whether another six deaths were related to the storms.\n\nIt was raining on Sunday morning in Porto Alegre, the capital of Rio Grande do Sul, and in other parts of the state, which could make rescue efforts even harder. Flooding from storms in the past few days has affected about two thirds of the nearly 500 towns and cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina, leaving more than 88,000 displaced.\n\nFloods have destroyed roads and bridges in several cities. The rains also have triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the Guaiba lake broke its banks by more than two meters (7 feet), hitting the highest water level on records, according to the national geological service. Porto Alegre's international airport has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nState Governor Eduardo Leite told reporters on Saturday evening that Rio Grande do Sul would need a \"Marshall Plan\" to recover from the storms and its consequences, referring to the U.S.-led plan for Europe's economic recovery after World War II.", "source": {"uri": "ntd.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NTD"}, {"uri": "8112962009", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "01:00:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T01:00:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T00:58:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/world/2024/05/501_374064.html", "title": "Death toll from southern Brazil rainfall rises to 78, many still missing", "body": "A drone view shows boats with volunteers searching for people isolated at houses at the flooded neighborhood of Mathias Velho in Canoas, at the Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil, May 5. Reuters-Yonhap\n\nThe death toll from heavy rains that have caused flooding in Brazil's southern state of Rio Grande do Sul has risen to at least 78, local authorities said on Sunday, with more than 115,000 people displaced.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva arrived in Rio Grande do Sul on Sunday morning with most members of his cabinet to discuss rescue and reconstruction efforts with local authorities.\n\n\"Bureaucracy will not stand in our way, stopping us from recovering the state's greatness,\" Lula said at a press conference.\n\n\"It is a war scenario, and will need post-war measures,\" state governor Eduardo Leite added.\n\nVolunteers using boats, jet skis -- and even swimming -- have assisted in ongoing rescue efforts. In the state capital Porto Alegre, Fabiano Saldanha said he and three friends have used jet skis to save about 50 people from flood waters since Friday in islands that are part of the city.\n\n\"The only thing we hear when we enter a street is 'help,' 'help,'\" Saldanha said.\n\nThe death toll could still substantially increase as 105 people were reported missing on Sunday, up from about 70 the prior day, according to the state civil defense authority. It also said it was investigating whether another four deaths were related to the storms.\n\nFlooding from storms in the past few days has affected more than two thirds of the nearly 500 cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina, leaving more than 115,000 people displaced, according to authorities.\n\nFloods have destroyed roads and bridges in several cities. The rains also triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nAn area is affected by floods in Canoas, at the Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil, May 5. Reuters-Yonhap\n\nMore than 400,000 people were without power on Sunday evening, while nearly a third of the state's population was without water, authorities said.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the Guaiba lake breached its banks, hitting the highest water level on record, according to the national geological service. Porto Alegre's international airport has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nAt a makeshift rescue center in Porto Alegre, Kaeli Moraes described being rescued along with her husband and their three children when the water had nearly reached the second floor of their house.\n\n\"There was flooding in September, then in November, and now this one. It is only getting worse,\" Moraes said.\n\nIn the city of Canoas, near Porto Alegre, Julio Manichesque, 76, was rescued by volunteers after he had stayed since Friday on the roof of the house where he has lived for 52 years.\n\n\"I have never seen that much water,\" Manichesque said.\n\nDuring his weekly address to crowds in St. Peter's Square in Vatican City, Pope Francis said on Sunday he was praying for the people of Rio Grande do Sul. {"uri": "8112564855", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:25:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:25:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:24:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13384941/Death-toll-southern-Brazil-rainfall-rises-75-missing.html", "title": "Death toll from southern Brazil rainfall rises to 75, many still...", "body": "PORTO ALEGRE/CANOAS, May 5 (Reuters) - The death toll from heavy rains that have caused flooding in Brazil's southern state of Rio Grande do Sul has risen to at least 75, local authorities said on Sunday, with tens of thousands of people displaced.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva arrived in Rio Grande do Sul on Sunday, along with most members of his cabinet, to discuss rescue and reconstruction works with local authorities.\n\nThe death toll could still substantially increase as 103 people were reported missing on Sunday, up from about 70 the prior day, according to the state civil defense authority. It also said it was investigating whether another six deaths were related to the storms.\n\nIt was raining on Sunday morning in Porto Alegre, the capital of Rio Grande do Sul, and in other parts of the state, which could make rescue efforts even harder. Flooding from storms in the past few days has affected about two thirds of the nearly 500 towns and cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina, leaving more than 88,000 displaced.\n\nFloods have destroyed roads and bridges in several cities. The rains also have triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the Guaiba lake broke its banks by more than two meters (7 feet), hitting the highest water level on records, according to the national geological service. Porto Alegre's international airport has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nState Governor Eduardo Leite told reporters on Saturday evening that Rio Grande do Sul would need a \"Marshall Plan\" to recover from the storms and its consequences, referring to the U.S.-led plan for Europe's economic recovery after World War Two.\n\nIn the city of Canoas, near Porto Alegre, Julio Manichesque, 76, was rescued by volunteers after he had stayed since Friday on the roof of the house where he has lived for 52 years.\n\n\"I have never seen that much water,\" Manichesque said.\n\nDuring his weekly address to crowds in St. Peter's Square in Vatican City, Pope Francis said on Sunday he was praying for the people of the state.\n\n\"I assure my prayers for the people of the state of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil, affected by major floods. May the Lord receive the dead, comfort their families and all those who had to leave their homes,\" the pope said.\n\n(Reporting by Renan Mattos in Porto Alegre and Amanda Perobelli in Canoas; additional reporting by Andre Romani and Eduardo Simoes in Sao Paulo, and Angelo Amante in Vatican City, Editing by Angus MacSwan and Will Dunham)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-05-345454811", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:48:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:48:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:48:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.industriesnews.net/news/274340958/flooding-death-toll-in-brazil-climbs-to-57-dozens-missing", "title": "Flooding death toll in Brazil climbs to 57, dozens missing", "body": "sao paulo, brazil - The death toll from rains in Brazil's southernmost state of Rio Grande do Sul rose to 57, local authorities said Saturday afternoon, while dozens still have not been accounted for.\n\nRio Grande do Sul's civil defense authority said 67 people were still missing and more than 32,000 had been displaced as storms have affected nearly two thirds of the 497 cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina.\n\nFloods destroyed roads and bridges in several regions of the state. The storm also triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant. A second dam in the city of Bento Goncalves is also at risk of collapsing, authorities said.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the capital of Rio Grande do Sul, the Guaiba River broke its banks, flooding streets.\n\nA drone view shows a flooded city center after people were evacuated in Porto Alegre, in Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil, May 4, 2024.\n\nPorto Alegre's international airport has suspended all flights for an indefinite period.\n\nRain is expected in the northern and northeastern regions of the state in the next 36 hours, but the volume of precipitation has been declining, and should be well below the peak seen earlier in the week, according to the state meteorology authority.\n\nStill, 'river water levels should stay high for some days,' Governor Eduardo Leite said Saturday in a live video on his social media, adding it is difficult to determine for how long.\n\nPeople react after being rescued from flood in Porto Alegre, in Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil, May 4, 2024.\n\nRio Grande do Sul is at a geographical meeting point between tropical and polar atmospheres, which has created a weather pattern with periods of intense rain and others of drought.\n\nLocal scientists believe the pattern has been intensifying due to climate change.\n\nHeavy rains had already hit Rio Grande do Sul last September, as an extratropical cyclone caused floods that killed more than 50 people.\n\nThat came after more than two years of a persistent drought due to the La Nina phenomenon, with only scarce showers.\n\nReuters is a news agency founded in 1851 and owned by the Thomson Reuters Corporation based in Toronto, Canada. {"uri": "8112568001", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:28:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:28:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:28:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/death-toll-from-southern-brazil-rainfall-rises-to-75-many-still-missing/article_d0ff78ec-70b3-512b-bc87-95dbb558503e.html", "title": "Death toll from southern Brazil rainfall rises to 75, many still missing", "body": "PORTO ALEGRE/CANOAS (Reuters) -The death toll from heavy rains that have caused flooding in Brazil's southern state of Rio Grande do Sul has risen to at least 75, local authorities said on Sunday, with tens of thousands of people displaced.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva arrived in Rio Grande do Sul on Sunday, along with most members of his cabinet, to discuss rescue and reconstruction works with local authorities.\n\nThe death toll could still substantially increase as 103 people were reported missing on Sunday, up from about 70 the prior day, according to the state civil defense authority. It also said it was investigating whether another six deaths were related to the storms.\n\nIt was raining on Sunday morning in Porto Alegre, the capital of Rio Grande do Sul, and in other parts of the state, which could make rescue efforts even harder. Flooding from storms in the past few days has affected about two thirds of the nearly 500 towns and cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina, leaving more than 88,000 displaced.\n\nFloods have destroyed roads and bridges in several cities. The rains also have triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the Guaiba lake broke its banks by more than two meters (7 feet), hitting the highest water level on records, according to the national geological service. Porto Alegre's international airport has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nState Governor Eduardo Leite told reporters on Saturday evening that Rio Grande do Sul would need a \"Marshall Plan\" to recover from the storms and its consequences, referring to the U.S.-led plan for Europe's economic recovery after World War Two.\n\nIn the city of Canoas, near Porto Alegre, Julio Manichesque, 76, was rescued by volunteers after he had stayed since Friday on the roof of the house where he has lived for 52 years.\n\n\"I have never seen that much water,\" Manichesque said.\n\nDuring his weekly address to crowds in St. Peter's Square in Vatican City, Pope Francis said on Sunday he was praying for the people of the state.\n\n\"I assure my prayers for the people of the state of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil, affected by major floods. May the Lord receive the dead, comfort their families and all those who had to leave their homes,\" the pope said.\n\n(Reporting by Renan Mattos in Porto Alegre and Amanda Perobelli in Canoas; additional reporting by Andre Romani and Eduardo Simoes in Sao Paulo, and Angelo Amante in Vatican City, Editing by Angus MacSwan and Will Dunham)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "8112077398", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "08:33:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T08:33:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T08:32:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://en.ammonnews.net/article/72422", "title": "Death toll from rains in southern Brazil climbs to 56", "body": "Ammon News - Heavy rains in Brazil's southernmost state of Rio Grande do Sul this week killed at least 55 people, local authorities said on Saturday evening, while dozens remain unaccounted for.\n\nRio Grande do Sul's civil defense authority said 74 people were still missing and more than 69,000 had been displaced as storms in the last few days have affected nearly two thirds of the 497 cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina.\n\nThe local authority said it is now investigating whether another seven deaths were related to the storms, after earlier in the day it had reported a total of more than 55 deaths.\n\nFloods destroyed roads and bridges in several regions of the state. The storm also triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant. A second dam in the city of Bento Goncalves is also at risk of collapsing, authorities said.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the capital of Rio Grande do Sul, the Guaiba lake broke its banks, flooding streets.\n\nPorto Alegre's international airport has suspended all flights for an indefinite period.\n\nState Governor Eduardo Leite told reporters on Saturday evening that Rio Grande do Sul would need a \"Marshall Plan\" to recover.\n\nBrazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, who had visited Rio Grande do Sul on Thursday, will travel back to the state on Sunday to follow the rescue efforts, his chief of communication Paulo Pimenta said on Saturday.\n\nLula said on X that his government is in constant contact with state and cities' authorities to support the region with whatever they need.\n\nRains are expected in the northern and northeastern regions of the state until Sunday, but the volume of precipitation has been declining, and should be well below the peak seen earlier in the week, according to the state meteorology authority.\n\nStill, \"rivers water levels should stay high for some days\", Leite said earlier on Saturday.\n\nRio Grande do Sul is at a geographical meeting point between tropical and polar atmospheres, which has created a weather pattern with periods of intense rains and others of drought.\n\nLocal scientists believe the pattern has been intensifying due to climate change.\n\nReuters", "source": {"uri": "en.ammonnews.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "\u0648\u0643\u0627\u0644\u0647 \u0639\u0645\u0648\u0646 Although it is not expected to be significant in volume terms, water levels are already high in many places, and the soil saturated.\n\nWeather forecaster MetSul said in a statement the region could face more \"very large\" floods \"of serious proportions\".\n\nGovernment officials reiterated that help was coming for Rio Grande do Sul, with the federal government saying it would soon announce {"uri": "8115725927", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "14:21:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T14:21:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T14:15:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13391799/Too-water-not-Brazils-flooded-south-struggles-basic-goods.html", "title": "Too much water, and not enough: Brazil's flooded south struggles to...", "body": "TORRES, Brazil (AP) - A mayor in southern Brazil asked residents to ration water Tuesday in a state capital where some 80% of the population is without running water, a week after massive flooding that has left at least 90 people dead and more than 130 missing.\n\nEfforts were continuing to rescue people stranded by the f loods in the southern state of Rio Grande do Sul, as more rains were forecast for the region into next week. The capital, Porto Alegre, has been virtually cut off, with the airport and bus station closed and main roads blocked due to the floodwaters.\n\nFive of the city\u00b4s six water treatment facilities aren\u00b4t working, and Porto Alegre Mayor Sebasti\u00e3o Melo ordered that water be used exclusively for \"essential consumption.\" Local shops have also been short on water supplies.\n\n\"We are living an unprecedented natural disaster and everyone needs to help,\" Melo told journalists. \"The shortage is real and it will take some time until it goes back to normal.\"\n\n\"I am getting water trucks to soccer fields and people will have to go there to get their water in bottles. I cannot get them to go home to home,\" the mayor added.\n\nThe most urgent need is drinking water, but food and personal hygiene products are also in short supply. Other Brazilian states are mobilizing trucks with donations bound for Rio Grande do Sul.\n\nA woman, cradling a dog, wades through a street flooded by heavy rains in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil, Monday, May 6, 2024. (AP Photo/Carlos Macedo)\n\nResidents in Rio Grande do Sul who are able to flee are doing so, over fears of shortage and the spread of disease. However, it's difficult for many to leave Porto Alegre with main access roads blocked by floodwaters. The city's airport and main bus terminal are filled with water and closed for the foreseeable future.\n\nThe downpour has stopped for now, but a looming cold front will bring more severe rain starting Tuesday night, mainly in the southern part of the state, according to the National Meteorological Institute. Rainfall is could exceed 150 millimeters (5.9 inches) by early Wednesday.\n\nLate Monday, Rio Grande do Sul's Gov. Eduardo Leite issued an alert for several cities close to the massive Patos Lagoon. The floodwaters in Porto Alegre and other cities pass through the lagoon to the sea.\n\n\"The water level will rise and it will affect you,\" he said in a video broadcast on his social media channels. \"Please, believe the alerts and help us save lives. Let's reduce the damage so we can be together to rebuild.\"\n\nDamage from the rains has already forced more than 150,000 people from their homes. An additional 50,000 have taken refuge in schools, gymnasiums and other temporary shelters.\n\nBrazil\u00b4s President Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva visited Rio Grande do Sul for a second time on Sunday, accompanied by Defense Minister Jos\u00e9 M\u00facio, Finance Minister Fernando Haddad and Environment Minister Marina Silva, among others.\n\nDuring Mass at the Vatican on Sunday, Pope Francis said he was praying for the state\u00b4s population.\n\nPublic health experts say there is growing risk of disease as much of the region remains underwater, warning that cases of dengue fever and leptospirosis in particular could rise sharply within days\n\nSecurity is another concern. Rio Grande do Sul\u00b4s public security secretariat said in a statement that police will beef up operations to prevent looting and theft. Several volunteers working on rescue operations have been robbed as they tried to help in the Porto Alegre metropolitan region.\n\nAlso on Monday, three top-tier Rio Grande do Sul state soccer clubs whose stadiums are flooded urged Brazil\u00b4s soccer federation to suspend their national league matches for the next 20 days because of the flooding. Brazil\u00b4s soccer confederation said it would consider the request.\n\nAP journalist Gabriela S\u00e1 Pessoa contributed from Sao Paulo.\n\nView of an area flooded by heavy rains in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil, Monday, May 6, 2024. It also said it was investigating whether another six deaths were related to the storms.\n\nIt was raining on Sunday morning in Porto Alegre, the capital of Rio Grande do Sul, and in other parts of the state, which could make rescue efforts even harder. Flooding from storms in the past few days has affected about two thirds of the nearly 500 towns and cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina, leaving more than 88,000 displaced.", {"uri": "8116732523", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "05:48:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T05:48:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T05:48:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/too-much-water-and-not-enough-brazils-flooded-south-struggles-to-access-basic-goods/article_be80c721-4d61-5831-8262-5b0704535978.html", "title": "Too much water, and not enough: Brazil's flooded south struggles to access basic goods", "body": "People rest in a shelter after their homes were flooded by heavy rains in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil, Saturday, May 4, 2024.\n\nPORTO ALEGRE, Brazil (AP) -- The mayor of a major city in southern Brazil on Tuesday pleaded with residents to comply with his water rationing decree, given that some four-fifths of the population is without running water, a week after major flooding that has left at least 90 people dead and more than 130 others missing.\n\nEfforts were continuing to rescue people stranded by the floods in the southern state of Rio Grande do Sul, as more rains were forecast for the region into next week. The capital, Porto Alegre, has been virtually cut off, with the airport and bus station closed and main roads blocked because of the floodwaters.\n\nThe floods in Brazil are among extreme weather events being seen around the world.\n\nYoga teacher Maria Vit\u00f3ria Jorge's apartment building in downtown Porto Alegre is flooded, so she's leaving it behind, having withdrawn about 8,000 reais ($1,600) from her savings to rent an apartment for herself and her parents elsewhere in the state.\n\n\"I can't shower at home, wash the dishes or even have drinkable water,\" the 35-year-old Jorge said in her car as she prepared to travel. She had just a gallon of water for the 200-kilometer (125-mile) drive to the city of Torres, so far unaffected by the floods.\n\nFive of the Porto Alegre's six water treatment facilities aren't working, and Porto Alegre Mayor Sebasti\u00e3o Melo on Monday decreed that water be used exclusively for \"essential consumption.\"\n\n\"We are living an unprecedented natural disaster and everyone needs to help,\" Melo told journalists. \"I am getting water trucks to soccer fields and people will have to go there to get their water in bottles. I cannot get them to go home to home.\"\n\nThe most urgent need is drinking water, but food and personal hygiene products are also in short supply. Other Brazilian states are mobilizing trucks with donations bound for Rio Grande do Sul.\n\nThere were long lines and empty shelves at supermarkets in Porto Alegre on Tuesday. Some people have tried to buy bottled water since the weekend, and when they could find it, their purchases were limited to two five-liter (1.3-gallon) bottles.\n\nPublic health experts say there is also growing risk of disease as much of the region remains submerged, warning that cases of dengue fever and leptospirosis, a bacterial disease, in particular could rise sharply within days.\n\nAdriano Hueck on Tuesday was attempting to retrieve medicine stocked at a friend's warehouse, which is partially flooded.\n\n\"If we can save some of it, there's still a chance it can be useful in hospitals,\" said 53-year-old Hueck, who then pointed toward another part of the city. \"My house is somewhere there. You can't even see its roof now.\"\n\nLike Jorge, the yoga teacher, residents in Rio Grande do Sul who are able to flee are doing so, amid fears of shortage and disease. However, it's difficult for many to leave Porto Alegre with main access roads blocked by floodwaters. The city's airport and main bus terminal are filled with water and closed for the foreseeable future.\n\nClose to the airport, about 100 people of a nearby slum set up tents on the road, hoping to return to their shacks on small boats to try to save some of their belongings. Some roasted chunks of meat on improvised grills.\n\nThe downpour has stopped for now, but a looming cold front will bring more severe rain starting Tuesday night, mainly in the southern part of the state, according to the National Meteorological Institute. Rainfall could exceed 150 millimeters (nearly six inches) by early Wednesday.\n\nLate Monday, Rio Grande do Sul Gov. Eduardo Leite issued an alert for several cities close to the huge Patos Lagoon. The floodwaters in Porto Alegre and other cities pass through the lagoon to the sea.\n\n\"The water level will rise and it will affect you,\" he said in a video broadcast on his social media channels. \"Please, believe the alerts and help us save lives. Let's reduce the damage so we can be together to rebuild.\"\n\nPorto Alegre's metropolitan region is one of Brazil's largest, home to around 4 million people.\n\nDamage from the rains has already forced more than 150,000 people from their homes. An additional 50,000 have taken refuge in schools, gymnasiums and other temporary shelters.\n\nBrazilian President Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva visited Rio Grande do Sul for a second time on Sunday, accompanied by Defense Minister Jos\u00e9 M\u00facio, Finance Minister Fernando Haddad and Environment Minister Marina Silva, among others.\n\nAuthorities said Monday that they are concerned about the risks of hypothermia, as the temperature should drop to 10 C (50 F) on Wednesday. On Tuesday, Melo issued a plea for more donations of blankets.\n\nAnd it isn't just residents who are at risk.\n\n\"Our personnel has been wet for five days, shivering in the cold, staying up all night, in deficient sanitary conditions, because we're sharing the same facilities with the displaced,\" Gen. Hertz Pires do Nascimento, the army commander of Brazil's southern region, told journalists.\n\nDuring Mass at the Vatican on Sunday, Pope Francis said he was praying for the state's population.\n\nSecurity is another concern. Rio Grande do Sul's public security secretariat said in a statement that police will beef up operations to prevent looting and theft. Brazil's national guard is mobilizing to the state to reinforce security.\n\n\"Even a boat was stolen this morning from the people working on the rescue. Jet Skis and houses were looted. This is deplorable and must be denounced,\" Paulo Pimenta, Lula's spokesperson, said Tuesday at a news conference.\n\nThe flood disaster is also likely to affect the South American country's food supplies. Rio Grande do Sul produces 70% of an basic Brazilian foodstuff: rice.\n\n\"With the rains, I think we've definitely delayed the harvest in Rio Grande do Sul. So, if needed to balance production, we'll have to import rice, import beans,\" Lula said in a radio interview at Brazil's public broadcaster.\n\nPessoa reported from Sao Paulo.", "source": {"uri": In the state capital Porto Alegre, Fabiano Saldanha said he and three friends have used jet skis to save about 50 people from flood waters since Friday in islands that are part of the city.\n\n\"The only thing we hear when we enter a street is 'help,' 'help,'\" Saldanha said.\n\nThe death toll could still substantially increase as 105 people were reported missing on Sunday, up from about 70 the prior day, according to the state civil defense authority. It also said it was investigating whether another four deaths were related to the storms.\n\nFlooding from storms in the past few days has affected more than two thirds of the nearly 500 cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina, leaving more than 115,000 people displaced, according to authorities.\n\nFloods have destroyed roads and bridges in several cities. The rains also triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nMore than 400,000 people were without power on Sunday evening, while nearly a third of the state's population was without water, authorities said.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the Guaiba lake breached its banks, hitting the highest water level on record, according to the national geological service. Porto Alegre's international airport has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nAt a makeshift rescue center in Porto Alegre, Kaeli Moraes described being rescued along with her husband and their three children when the water had nearly reached the second floor of their house.\n\nREAD MORE: Death toll from southern Brazil rains rises to 29, Lula visits region\n\n\"There was flooding in September, then in November, and now this one. It is only getting worse,\" Moraes said.\n\nIn the city of Canoas, near Porto Alegre, Julio Manichesque, 76, was rescued by volunteers after he had stayed since Friday on the roof of the house where he has lived for 52 years.\n\n\"I have never seen that much water,\" Manichesque said.\n\nDuring his weekly address to crowds in St Peter's Square in Vatican City, Pope Francis said on Sunday he was condolences.\n\nThe tragic event has claimed numerous lives and caused widespread displacement and destruction.\n\nPresident Ali reached out to his Brazilian counterpart, President Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva, to express solidarity with the Brazilian people during this harrowing time.\n\nEmphasizing the resilient spirit of the Brazilians, President Ali conveyed his confidence in their ability to overcome the adversity posed by this natural disaster.\n\nSince April 29, torrential rains have relentlessly pounded Rio Grande do Sul, leading to severe flooding in urban areas.\n\nHome to over 11 million people, this southern state -- bordering Uruguay and Argentina -- has seen hundreds of thousands displaced due to the rising waters.\n\nThe floods have led to at least 78 fatalities, with over 130 individuals still reported missing.\n\nAuthorities have declared this the worst flooding the region has seen in more than eight decades, highlighting the severity and scale of the disaster.\n\nPresident Lula da Silva, along with members of his cabinet, has visited the affected regions, attributing the crisis to climate change.\n\nIn a move to address immediate and future risks, he has committed to funding reconstruction efforts and enhancing infrastructure to better withstand similar events, affirming the government's proactive stance in combating the impacts of climate Although it is not expected to be significant in volume, water levels are already high in many places and the soil saturated.\n\nWeather forecaster MetSul said in a statement the region could face more \"very large\" floods \"of serious proportions.\"\n\nGovernment officials reiterated that help was coming for Rio Grande do Sul, with the federal government saying it would soon announce credit lines to assist companies, farmers, cities and the state government.\n\n\"We understand the difficult financial situation faced by Rio Grande do Sul,\" President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva said at an event in Brasilia, adding he wanted to make sure the state would get \"everything it is entitled to.\"\n\n\"We still don't know the exact dimension of the floods, that will only be clear to us when {"uri": "8113278499", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:47:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:47:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T06:47:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://en.apa.az/america/death-toll-from-southern-brazil-rainfall-rises-to-78-many-still-missing-436081", "title": "Death toll from southern Brazil rainfall rises to 78, many still missing", "body": "The death toll from heavy rains that have caused flooding in Brazil's southern state of Rio Grande do Sul has risen to at least 78, local authorities said on Sunday, with more than 115,000 people displaced, APA reports citing Reuters.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva arrived in Rio Grande do Sul on Sunday morning with most members of his cabinet to discuss rescue and reconstruction efforts with local authorities.\n\n\"Bureaucracy will not stand in our way, stopping us from recovering the state's greatness,\" Lula said at a press conference.\n\n\"It is a war scenario, and will need post-war measures,\" state governor Eduardo Leite added.\n\nVolunteers using boats, jet skis - and even swimming - have assisted in ongoing rescue efforts. In the state capital Porto Alegre, Fabiano Saldanha said he and three friends have used jet skis to save about 50 people from flood waters since Friday in islands that are part of the city.\n\n\"The only thing we hear when we enter a street is 'help,' 'help,'\" Saldanha said.\n\nThe death toll could still substantially increase as 105 people were reported missing on Sunday, up from about 70 the prior day, according to the state civil defense authority. It also said it was investigating whether another four deaths were related to the storms.\n\nFlooding from storms in the past few days has affected more than two thirds of the nearly 500 cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina, leaving more than 115,000 people displaced, according to authorities.\n\nFloods have destroyed roads and bridges in several cities. The rains also triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nMore than 400,000 people were without power on Sunday evening, while nearly a third of the state's population was without water, authorities said.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the Guaiba lake breached its banks, hitting the highest water level on record, according to the national geological service. Porto Alegre's international airport has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nAt a makeshift rescue center in Porto Alegre, Kaeli Moraes described being rescued along with her husband and their three children when the water had nearly reached the second floor of their house.\n\n\"There was flooding in September, then in November, and now this one. It is only getting worse,\" Moraes said.\n\nIn the city of Canoas, near Porto Alegre, Julio Manichesque, 76, was rescued by volunteers after he had stayed since Friday on the roof of the house where he has lived for 52 years.\n\n\"I have never seen that much water,\" Manichesque said.\n\nDuring his weekly address to crowds in St. Peter's Square in Vatican City, Pope Francis said on Sunday he was praying for the people of Rio Grande do Sul.\n\nTikTok vows to fight 'unconstitutional' US ban House votes to advance foreign aid bills, despite GOP defections Indigenous people protest over ancestral The storm also triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant. A second dam in the city of Bento Goncalves is also at risk of collapsing, authorities said.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the capital of Rio Grande do Sul, the Guaiba lake broke its banks, flooding streets.\n\nPorto Alegre's international airport has suspended all flights for an indefinite period.\n\nState Governor Eduardo Leite told reporters on Saturday evening that Rio Grande do Sul would need a \"Marshall Plan\" to recover from the storms and its consequences, referring to a plan for Europe's economic recovery after World War Two.\n\nBrazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, who had visited Rio Grande do Sul on Thursday, will travel back to the state on Sunday to follow the rescue efforts, his chief of communication Paulo Pimenta said on Saturday.\n\nLula said on X that his government is in constant contact with state and cities' authorities to support the region with whatever they need.\n\nRains are expected in the northern and northeastern regions of the state until Sunday, but the volume of precipitation has been declining, and should be well below the peak seen earlier in the week, according to the state meteorology authority.\n\nStill, \"rivers water levels In the state capital Porto Alegre, Fabiano Saldanha said he and three friends have used jet skis to save about 50 people from flood waters since Friday in islands that are part of the city.\n\n\"The only thing we hear when we enter a street is 'help,' 'help,'\" Saldanha said.\n\nThe death toll could still substantially increase as 105 people were reported missing on Sunday, up from about 70 the prior day, according to the state civil defense authority. The rains also triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nMore than 400,000 people were without power on Sunday evening, while nearly a third of the state's population was without water, authorities said.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the Guaiba lake breached its banks, hitting the highest water level on record, according to the national geological service. It is only getting worse,\" Moraes said.\n\nIn the city of Canoas, near Porto Alegre, Julio Manichesque, 76, was rescued by volunteers after he had stayed since Friday on the roof of the house where he has lived for 52 years.\n\n\"I have never seen that much water,\" Manichesque said.\n\nDuring his weekly address to crowds in St. Peter's Square in Vatican City, Pope Francis said on Sunday he was {"uri": "8113071187", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:29:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:29:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:28:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.wionews.com/world/death-toll-after-floods-in-southern-brazil-rises-to-78-more-than-115000-displaced-718303", "title": "Death toll after floods in southern Brazil rises to 78, more than 115,000 displaced", "body": "In Porto Alegre, the capital of the state of Rio Grande do Sul, residents reportedly stood on rooftops hoping to be rescued as others navigated the flooded streets in canoes or small boats.\n\nThe death toll after heavy rains which led to floods in southern Brazil rose to at least 78, said local authorities on Sunday (May 5), as they scrambled to rescue people from what is being called the region's largest-ever climate catastrophe.\n\nThe floods triggered by torrential rain in Brazil's southern state of Rio Grande do Sul have killed at least 78 people, so far. According to local authorities, this number could rise as around 105 people have been reported missing as of Sunday, up from 70 the prior day.\n\nThe storms and floods have affected more than two-thirds of the nearly 500 cities in the state over the past couple of days. The rains also triggered landslides, leading to the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nAs of Sunday evening, more than 400,000 people were left without power and nearly a third of the state's population was without water, according to the local authorities.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the capital of the state, residents reportedly stood on rooftops hoping to be rescued as others navigated the flooded streets in canoes or small boats.\n\nThe Guaiba lake, in the state capital, breached its banks, hitting the highest water level on record, according to local authorities.\n\nOver 3,000 soldiers, firefighters and other rescuers were trying to reach residents who are trapped in their homes without water or electricity. The army personnel also set up field hospitals for hundreds of patients who had to be evacuated from regular hospitals.\n\nMeanwhile, civilians formed volunteer groups to gather basic supplies like life jackets and water. Some volunteers also used boats, jet skis, and even swimming to help in ongoing rescue efforts.\n\nAlso Read | Brazil floods: Nearly 70,000 forced from homes, death toll at 57\n\nFabiano Saldanha said he and three friends have used jet skis to save about 50 people from flood waters since Friday (May 3), according to Reuters.\n\n\"It is a war scenario, and will need post-war measures,\" said state governor Eduardo Leite, flanked by President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva.\n\nLula arrived in Rio Grande do Sul on Sunday morning with most members of his cabinet to discuss rescue and reconstruction efforts with local authorities.\n\n\"Bureaucracy will not stand in our way, stopping us from recovering the state's greatness,\" said the Brazilian president.\n\nAlso Read | Hamas official says Cairo truce meeting ends, delegation to leave for Doha\n\nIn addition to Porto Alegre, around 341 towns and villages in the state have been hit by the flooding. The international airport in the state capital suspended all flights on Friday, with its runways underwater.\n\nClimatologist Francisco Eliseu Aquino called the situation in Rio Grande do Sul a \"a disastrous cocktail\" of climate change and the El Nino effect.\n\n\"Rio Grande do Sul has always been a meeting point between tropical and polar air masses,\" Aquino told AFP, adding that these \"interactions intensified with climate change\" and created \"a disastrous cocktail that makes the atmosphere more unstable and encourages storms.\"", "source": {"uri": "wionews.com", "dataType": Civil defense figures showed that 417 of Rio Grande do Sul's 497 towns have been affected by the heavy rains.\n\nThe death toll from heavy rains that swamped Rio Grande do Sul in recent days has climbed to 100, local civil defense said on Wednesday, as Brazil's southernmost state braces for more rain in coming hours and days. The storms have caused floods which destroyed bridges and buildings, turning streets into rivers and leaving more than 163,000 displaced in Rio Grande do Sul, which borders Uruguay and Argentina.\n\nAccording to the state civil defense authority, 128 people are still missing. \"We've lost everything,\" said Adriana Freitas, in state capital Porto Alegre. \"It's sad when we see the city, our house, in the middle of the water; it seems like it's over, that the world has ended.\"\n\nBrazil's national center for natural disasters said on Tuesday that the southern area of the state was under \"high risk\" of more floods on Wednesday, with rainfall expected to restart. Although it is not expected to be significant in volume terms, water levels are already high in many places, and the soil saturated. Weather forecaster MetSul said in a statement the region could face more \"very large\" floods \"of serious proportions\".\n\nGovernment officials reiterated that help was coming for Rio Grande do Sul, with the federal government saying it would soon announce credit lines to assist companies, farmers, cities and the state government. \"We understand the difficult financial situation faced by Rio Grande do Sul,\" President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva said at an event in Brasilia, adding he wanted to make sure the state would get \"everything it is entitled to\".\n\n\"We still don't know the exact dimension of the floods, that will only be clear to us when the water levels return to normal,\" Lula said. {"uri": "8117852925", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:03:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:03:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T17:55:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13396993/Southern-Brazil-reeling-massive-flooding-faces-risk-new-storms.html", "title": "Southern Brazil is still reeling from massive flooding as it faces...", "body": "PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil (AP) - Authorities in southern Brazil rushed Wednesday to rescue survivors of massive flooding that has killed at least 100 people, but some residents refused to leave belongings behind while others returned to evacuated homes despite the risk of new storms.\n\nHeavy rains and flooding in the southern state of Rio Grande do Sul since last week also have left 128 people missing, authorities said. More than 230,000 have been displaced, and much of the region has been isolated by the floodwaters.\n\nMore storms are expected in the state, with lightning strikes and wind gusts reaching up to 100 kilometers per hour (62 mph) in the south, according to C\u00e1tia Valente, the meteorologist in the state\u00b4s situation room.\n\nStaffers of the state\u00b4s civil defense agency told The Associated Press they have been struggling to persuade residents of the city of Eldorado do Sul, one of the hardest hit by the floods, to leave their homes. It is located beside Porto Alegre, near the center of the state\u00b4s coastline. At least four people declined to evacuate.\n\nA flyover of Eldorado do Sul in a military helicopter showed hundreds of houses submerged, with only their roofs visible. Residents were using small boards, surfboards and personal watercraft to move around. Mayor Ernani de Freitas told local journalists that the city \"will be totally evacuated.\"\n\n\"It will take at least a year to recover,\" he said.\n\nCars sit on a submerged road in an area flooded by heavy rain in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Andre Penner)\n\nRio Grande do Sul's Gov. Eduardo Leite, speaking at a news conference late Tuesday, appealed to residents to stay out of harm's way, as the anticipated downpour may cause more severe flooding across the state.\n\n\"It isn't the time to return home,\" he said.\n\nThe civil defense agency's own urgent warning asking displaced residents not to return to flooded areas also stressed the risk of disease transmission.\n\nArmy Gen. Marcelo Zucco, one of the coordinators of rescue operations, told the AP his team is working at full speed before heavy rains that are forecast to hit the Porto Alegre area this weekend. Moderate rain was falling Wednesday afternoon in the city.\n\n\"We hope the next rains are not like those we saw, but there's no way to be sure there won't be trouble ahead of us,\" Zucco said.\n\n\"At this moment we are focusing on finishing rescue operations and starting logistical support to the population. That's bringing water, medication, food and transportation for the sick to some hospital,\" the general added.\n\nHe also said some improvement in conditions for the day helped his men finally access some areas by land.\n\nA report by the National Confederation of Municipalities estimates damages at 4.6 billion reais ($930 million) in nearly 80% of Rio Grande do Sul's municipalities.\n\nGov. Leite has said that the enormous impact will require something akin to the Marshall Plan for Europe's post-WWII recovery. Already the state has asked the federal government to suspend debt payments and create a fund for the southern region.\n\nOn Tuesday, Congress passed a decree declaring a state of calamity in Rio Grande do Sul until the end of the year, allowing the federal government to quickly allocate money to mitigate the catastrophe and rebuild regions affected by the floods, bypassing a spending cap. The vote united supporters and opponents of President Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva\u00b4s government.\n\n\"There is no limit to the public spending necessary to resolve the problem of the calamity that today is ravaging Rio Grande do Sul state,\" Planning and Budget Minister Simone Tebet told Radio Gaucho in an interview.\n\n____\n\nS\u00e1 Pessoa reported from Sao Paulo.\n\nThe city of Porto Alegre is flooded after heavy rain in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Andre Penner)\n\nA boat navigates through a flooded street after heavy rain in Canoas, Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Carlos Macedo)\n\nResidential buildings stand in flood water after heavy rain in Canoas, Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Carlos Macedo)\n\nPeople who evacuated their flooded homes rest in a shelter amid heavy rain in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Andre Penner)\n\nThe Gremio Arena and surrounding area are flooded after heavy rain in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Andre Penner)\n\nFILE - A woman is rescued from an area flooded by heavy rains in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil, Monday, May 6, 2024. In a world growing increasingly accustomed to wild weather swings, the last few days and weeks have seemingly taken those environmental extremes to a new level. (AP Photo/Carlos Macedo, File)\n\nA soldier helps a woman evacuate from a neighborhood flooded by heavy rains, in Canoas, Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil, Saturday, May 4, 2024. {"uri": "8116280084", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "21:30:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T21:30:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T21:29:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.wltribune.com/world-news/too-much-water-or-not-enough-as-floods-ravage-brazil-7355040", "title": "Too much water, or not enough as floods ravage Brazil", "body": "At least 90 people dead and more than 130 missing in the country's south\n\nA mayor in southern Brazil asked residents to ration water Tuesday in a state capital where some 80% of the population is without running water, a week after massive flooding that has left at least 90 people dead and more than 130 missing.\n\nEfforts were continuing to rescue people stranded by the f loods in the southern state of Rio Grande do Sul, as more rains were forecast for the region into next week. The capital, Porto Alegre, has been virtually cut off, with the airport and bus station closed and main roads blocked due to the floodwaters.\n\nFive of the city's six water treatment facilities aren't working, and Porto Alegre Mayor Sebasti\u00e3o Melo ordered that water be used exclusively for \"essential consumption.\" Local shops have also been short on water supplies.\n\n\"We are living an unprecedented natural disaster and everyone needs to help,\" Melo told journalists. \"The shortage is real and it will take some time until it goes back to normal.\"\n\n\"I am getting water trucks to soccer fields and people will have to go there to get their water in bottles. I cannot get them to go home to home,\" the mayor added.\n\nThe most urgent need is drinking water, but food and personal hygiene products are also in short supply. Other Brazilian states are mobilizing trucks with donations bound for Rio Grande do Sul.\n\nResidents in Rio Grande do Sul who are able to flee are doing so, over fears of shortage and the spread of disease. However, it's difficult for many to leave Porto Alegre with main access roads blocked by floodwaters. The city's airport and main bus terminal are filled with water and closed for the foreseeable future.\n\nThe downpour has stopped for now, but a looming cold front will bring more severe rain starting Tuesday night, mainly in the southern part of the state, according to the National Meteorological Institute. Rainfall is could exceed 150 millimeters (5.9 inches) by early Wednesday.\n\nLate Monday, Rio Grande do Sul's Gov. Eduardo Leite issued an alert for several cities close to the massive Patos Lagoon. The floodwaters in Porto Alegre and other cities pass through the lagoon to the sea.\n\n\"The water level will rise and it will affect you,\" he said in a video broadcast on his social media channels. \"Please, believe the alerts and help us save lives. Let's reduce the damage so we can be together to rebuild.\"\n\nDamage from the rains has already forced more than 150,000 people from their homes. An additional 50,000 have taken refuge in schools, gymnasiums and other temporary shelters.\n\nBrazil's President Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva visited Rio Grande do Sul for a second time on Sunday, accompanied by Defense Minister Jos\u00e9 M\u00facio, Finance Minister Fernando Haddad and Environment Minister Marina Silva, among others.\n\nDuring Mass at the Vatican on Sunday, Pope Francis said he was praying for the state's population.\n\nPublic health experts say there is growing risk of disease as much of the region remains underwater, warning that cases of dengue fever and leptospirosis in particular could rise sharply within days\n\nSecurity is another concern. Rio Grande do Sul's public security secretariat said in a statement that police will beef up operations to prevent looting and theft. Several volunteers working on rescue operations have been robbed as they tried to help in the Porto Alegre metropolitan region.\n\nAlso on Monday, three top-tier Rio Grande do Sul state soccer clubs whose stadiums are flooded urged Brazil's soccer federation to suspend their national league matches for the next 20 days because of the flooding. Brazil's soccer confederation said it would consider the request.\n\nREAD ALSO: Death toll passes 200 in flooding, Kenya postpones school reopening", "source": {"uri": "wltribune.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8116447583", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "00:49:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T00:49:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T00:49:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/too-much-water-and-not-enough-brazil-s-flooded-south-struggles-to-access-basic-goods-1.6877827", "title": "Too much water, and not enough: Brazil's flooded south struggles to access basic goods", "body": "The mayor of a major city in southern Brazil on Tuesday pleaded with residents to comply with his water rationing decree, given that some four-fifths of the population is without running water, a week after major flooding that has left at least 90 people dead and more than 130 others missing.\n\nEfforts were continuing to rescue people stranded by the floods in the southern state of Rio Grande do Sul, as more rains were forecast for the region into next week. The capital, Porto Alegre, has been virtually cut off, with the airport and bus station closed and main roads blocked because of the floodwaters.\n\nThe floods in Brazil are among extreme weather events being seen around the world.\n\nYoga teacher Maria Vit\u00f3ria Jorge's apartment building in downtown Porto Alegre is flooded, so she's leaving it behind, having withdrawn about 8,000 reais (US$1,600) from her savings to rent an apartment for herself and her parents elsewhere in the state.\n\n\"I can't shower at home, wash the dishes or even have drinkable water,\" the 35-year-old Jorge said in her car as she prepared to travel. She had just a gallon of water for the 200-kilometre (125-mile) drive to the city of Torres, so far unaffected by the floods.\n\nFive of the Porto Alegre's six water treatment facilities aren't working, and Porto Alegre Mayor Sebasti\u00e3o Melo on Monday decreed that water be used exclusively for \"essential consumption.\"\n\n\"We are living an unprecedented natural disaster and everyone needs to help,\" Melo told journalists. \"I am getting water trucks to soccer fields and people will have to go there to get their water in bottles. I cannot get them to go home to home.\"\n\nThe most urgent need is drinking water, but food and personal hygiene products are also in short supply. Other Brazilian states are mobilizing trucks with donations bound for Rio Grande do Sul.\n\nThere were long lines and empty shelves at supermarkets in Porto Alegre on Tuesday. Some people have tried to buy bottled water since the weekend, and when they could find it, their purchases were limited to two five-litre (1.3-gallon) bottles.\n\nPublic health experts say there is also growing risk of disease as much of the region remains submerged, warning that cases of dengue fever and leptospirosis, a bacterial disease, in particular could rise sharply within days.\n\nAdriano Hueck on Tuesday was attempting to retrieve medicine stocked at a friend's warehouse, which is partially flooded.\n\n\"If we can save some of it, there's still a chance it can be useful in hospitals,\" said 53-year-old Hueck, who then pointed toward another part of the city. \"My house is somewhere there. You can't even see its roof now.\"\n\nLike Jorge, the yoga teacher, residents in Rio Grande do Sul who are able to flee are doing so, amid fears of shortage and disease. However, it's difficult for many to leave Porto Alegre with main access roads blocked by floodwaters. The city's airport and main bus terminal are filled with water and closed for the foreseeable future.\n\nClose to the airport, about 100 people of a nearby slum set up tents on the road, hoping to return to their shacks on small boats to try to save some of their belongings. Some roasted chunks of meat on improvised grills.\n\nThe downpour has stopped for now, but a looming cold front will bring more severe rain starting Tuesday night, mainly in the southern part of the state, according to the National Meteorological Institute. Rainfall could exceed 150 millimetres (nearly six inches) by early Wednesday.\n\nLate Monday, Rio Grande do Sul Gov. Eduardo Leite issued an alert for several cities close to the huge Patos Lagoon. The floodwaters in Porto Alegre and other cities pass through the lagoon to the sea.\n\n\"The water level will rise and it will affect you,\" he said in a video broadcast on his social media channels. \"Please, believe the alerts and help us save lives. Let's reduce the damage so we can be together to rebuild.\"\n\nPorto Alegre's metropolitan region is one of Brazil's largest, home to around four million people.\n\nDamage from the rains has already forced more than 150,000 people from their homes. An additional 50,000 have taken refuge in schools, gymnasiums and other temporary shelters.\n\nBrazilian President Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva visited Rio Grande do Sul for a second time on Sunday, accompanied by Defense Minister Jos\u00e9 M\u00facio, Finance Minister Fernando Haddad and Environment Minister Marina Silva, among others.\n\nAuthorities said Monday that they are concerned about the risks of hypothermia, as the temperature should drop to 10 C (50 F) on Wednesday. On Tuesday, Melo issued a plea for more donations of blankets.\n\nAnd it isn't just residents who are at risk.\n\n\"Our personnel has been wet for five days, shivering in the cold, staying up all night, in deficient sanitary conditions, because we're sharing the same facilities with the displaced,\" Gen. Hertz Pires do Nascimento, the army commander of Brazil's southern region, told journalists.\n\nDuring Mass at the Vatican on Sunday, Pope Francis said he was praying for the state's population.\n\nSecurity is another concern. Rio Grande do Sul's public security secretariat said in a statement that police will beef up operations to prevent looting and theft. Brazil's national guard is mobilizing to the state to reinforce security.\n\n\"Even a boat was stolen this morning from the people working on the rescue. Jet Skis and houses were looted. This is deplorable and must be denounced,\" Paulo Pimenta, Lula's spokesperson, said Tuesday at a news conference.\n\nThe flood disaster is also likely to affect the South American country's food supplies. Rio Grande do Sul produces 70 per cent of an basic Brazilian foodstuff: rice.\n\n\"With the rains, I think we've definitely delayed the harvest in Rio Grande do Sul. So, if needed to balance production, we'll have to import rice, import beans,\" Lula said in a radio interview at Brazil's public broadcaster.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pope_Francis", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Pope Francis"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vatican_City", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Vatican City"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Vatican City"}}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Home", "label": "dmoz/Home", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Transgendered/Coming_Out", "label": "dmoz/Society/Transgendered/Coming Out", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Home/Do-It-Yourself", "label": "dmoz/Home/Do-It-Yourself", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/content/dam/ctvnews/en/images/2024/5/7/brazil-flooding-volunteers-2024-1-6877829-1715129055957.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9540542", "eventUri": "eng-9540542", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.0980392156862745, "wgt": 183, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-05-348210020", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "20:39:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T20:39:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T09:58:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/business/articles/2024-05-07/too-much-water-and-not-enough-brazils-flooded-south-struggles-to-access-basic-goods", "title": "Too Much Water, and Not Enough: Brazil's Flooded South Struggles to Access Basic Goods", "body": "PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil (AP) -- The mayor of a major city in southern Brazil on Tuesday pleaded with residents to comply with his water rationing decree, given that some four-fifths of the population is without running water, a week after major flooding that has left at least 90 people dead and more than 130 others missing.\n\nEfforts were continuing to rescue people stranded by the floods in the southern state of Rio Grande do Sul, as more rains were forecast for the region into next week. The capital, Porto Alegre, has been virtually cut off, with the airport and bus station closed and main roads blocked because of the floodwaters.\n\nThe floods in Brazil are among extreme weather events being seen around the world.\n\nYoga teacher Maria Vit\u00f3ria Jorge's apartment building in downtown Porto Alegre is flooded, so she's leaving it behind, having withdrawn about 8,000 reais ($1,600) from her savings to rent an apartment for herself and her parents elsewhere in the state.\n\n\"I can't shower at home, wash the dishes or even have drinkable water,\" the 35-year-old Jorge said in her car as she prepared to travel. She had just a gallon of water for the 200-kilometer (125-mile) drive to the city of Torres, so far unaffected by the floods.\n\nFive of the Porto Alegre's six water treatment facilities aren't working, and Porto Alegre Mayor Sebasti\u00e3o Melo on Monday decreed that water be used exclusively for \"essential consumption.\"\n\n\"We are living an unprecedented natural disaster and everyone needs to help,\" Melo told journalists. \"I am getting water trucks to soccer fields and people will have to go there to get their water in bottles. I cannot get them to go home to home.\"\n\nThe most urgent need is drinking water, but food and personal hygiene products are also in short supply. Other Brazilian states are mobilizing trucks with donations bound for Rio Grande do Sul.\n\nThere were long lines and empty shelves at supermarkets in Porto Alegre on Tuesday. Some people have tried to buy bottled water since the weekend, and when they could find it, their purchases were limited to two five-liter (1.3-gallon) bottles.\n\nPublic health experts say there is also growing risk of disease as much of the region remains submerged, warning that cases of dengue fever and leptospirosis, a bacterial disease, in particular could rise sharply within days.\n\nAdriano Hueck on Tuesday was attempting to retrieve medicine stocked at a friend's warehouse, which is partially flooded.\n\n\"If we can save some of it, there's still a chance it can be useful in hospitals,\" said 53-year-old Hueck, who then pointed toward another part of the city. \"My house is somewhere there. You can't even see its roof now.\"\n\nLike Jorge, the yoga teacher, residents in Rio Grande do Sul who are able to flee are doing so, amid fears of shortage and disease. However, it's difficult for many to leave Porto Alegre with main access roads blocked by floodwaters. The city's airport and main bus terminal are filled with water and closed for the foreseeable future.\n\nClose to the airport, about 100 people of a nearby slum set up tents on the road, hoping to return to their shacks on small boats to try to save some of their belongings. Some roasted chunks of meat on improvised grills.\n\nThe downpour has stopped for now, but a looming cold front will bring more severe rain starting Tuesday night, mainly in the southern part of the state, according to the National Meteorological Institute. Rainfall could exceed 150 millimeters (nearly six inches) by early Wednesday.\n\nLate Monday, Rio Grande do Sul Gov. Eduardo Leite issued an alert for several cities close to the huge Patos Lagoon. The floodwaters in Porto Alegre and other cities pass through the lagoon to the sea.\n\n\"The water level will rise and it will affect you,\" he said in a video broadcast on his social media channels. \"Please, believe the alerts and help us save lives. Let's reduce the damage so we can be together to rebuild.\"\n\nPorto Alegre's metropolitan region is one of Brazil's largest, home to around 4 million people.\n\nDamage from the rains has already forced more than 150,000 people from their homes. An additional 50,000 have taken refuge in schools, gymnasiums and other temporary shelters.\n\nBrazilian President Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva visited Rio Grande do Sul for a second time on Sunday, accompanied by Defense Minister Jos\u00e9 M\u00facio, Finance Minister Fernando Haddad and Environment Minister Marina Silva, among others.\n\nAuthorities said Monday that they are concerned about the risks of hypothermia, as the temperature should drop to 10 C (50 F) on Wednesday. On Tuesday, Melo issued a plea for more donations of blankets.\n\nAnd it isn't just residents who are at risk.\n\n\"Our personnel has been wet for five days, shivering in the cold, staying up all night, in deficient sanitary conditions, because we're sharing the same facilities with the displaced,\" Gen. Hertz Pires do Nascimento, the army commander of Brazil's southern region, told journalists.\n\nDuring Mass at the Vatican on Sunday, Pope Francis said he was praying for the state's population.\n\nSecurity is another concern. Rio Grande do Sul's public security secretariat said in a statement that police will beef up operations to prevent looting and theft. Brazil's national guard is mobilizing to the state to reinforce security.\n\n\"Even a boat was stolen this morning from the people working on the rescue. Jet Skis and houses were looted. This is deplorable and must be denounced,\" Paulo Pimenta, Lula's spokesperson, said Tuesday at a news conference.\n\nThe flood disaster is also likely to affect the South American country's food supplies. Rio Grande do Sul produces 70% of an basic Brazilian foodstuff: rice.\n\n\"With the rains, I think we've definitely delayed the harvest in Rio Grande do Sul. So, if needed to balance production, we'll have to import rice, import beans,\" Lula said in a radio interview at Brazil's public broadcaster.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. The capital, Porto Alegre, has been virtually cut off, with the airport and bus station closed and main roads blocked because of the floodwaters.\n\nYoga teacher Maria Vitoria Jorge's apartment building in downtown Porto Alegre is flooded, so she's leaving it behind, having withdrawn about 8,000 reais ($1,600) from her savings to rent an apartment for herself and her parents elsewhere in the state.\n\n\"I can't shower at home, wash the dishes or even have drinkable water,\" the 35-year-old Jorge said in her car as she prepared to travel.
