{"uri": "2024-05-349604212", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:04:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:04:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:53:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://english.alarabiya.net/News/world/2024/05/09/southern-brazil-floods-death-toll-surpasses-100-as-devastation-continues", "title": "Southern Brazil floods: Death toll surpasses 100 as devastation continues", "body": "The death toll from devastating floods that have ravaged southern Brazil for days surpassed 100 on Wednesday, authorities said, as the search for dozens of missing people was interrupted by fresh storms.\n\nSome 400 municipalities have been affected by the worst natural calamity ever to hit the state of Rio Grande do Sul, with hundreds of people injured and more than 160,000 forced from their homes.\n\nFor all the latest headlines follow our Google News channel online or via the app.\n\nMany have no access to drinking water or electricity -- or even the means to call for help, with telephone and internet services down in many places.\n\nOn Tuesday, state governor Eduardo Leite had warned the human toll was likely to rise as \"the emergency is continuing to develop\" in the state capital of Porto Alegre and other cities and towns.\n\nSome 15,000 soldiers, firefighters, police and volunteers were at work across the state, many in boats and jet skis, to rescue those trapped and transport aid.\n\nBut in Porto Alegre the rains returned on Wednesday, halting evacuation efforts.\n\nThe mayor's office urged rescue boats to suspend their activities, citing the risk of electric shocks from lightning and strong winds of over 80 kilometers (50 miles) per hour.\n\nAuthorities urged people not to return to affected areas due to possible landslide and health hazards.\n\n\"Contaminated water can transmit diseases,\" civil defense spokeswoman Sabrina Ribas warned on Wednesday.\n\nMany people have been loath to leave their homes for the safety of shelters amid reports of abandoned properties being looted.\n\nThe National Confederation of Municipalities said about 61,000 homes -- down from an earlier estimate of 100,000 -- had been damaged or destroyed by unprecedented rains and floods in the state, with losses estimated at about 6.3 billion reais (some $1.2 billion.)\n\nDamage to schools, hospitals and municipal buildings amounted to about $69 million.\n\nPorto Alegre is home to about 1.4 million people and the larger metropolitan area has more than double that number.\n\nThe state's Guaiba River, which runs through Porto Alegre, reached historic levels and five dams are at risk of rupturing, with two of them in \"imminent\" danger.\n\n'A parallel universe'\n\nThere were queues at public taps and wells as officials warned that the most urgent need for people stranded by impassable roads, collapsed bridges and flooded homes was drinking water.\n\nOnly two of Porto Alegre's six water treatment plants were functioning, the mayor's office said Tuesday, and hospitals and shelters were being supplied by tankers.\n\nHelicopters were delivering water and food to communities most in need, while work continued on restoring road access.\n\nThe Brazilian Navy was to send its \"Atlantic\" vessel -- Latin America's largest -- to Rio Grande do Sul on Wednesday with two mobile water treatment stations.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has vowed there would be \"no lack of resources to meet the needs of Rio Grande do Sul.\"\n\nIn Gasometro, a part of Porto Alegre popular with tourists, the water continued to rise Wednesday, complicating rescue efforts.\n\n\"You can only cross on foot or by boat. There is no other way,\" 30-year-old resident Luan Pas told AFP next to a street turned into a stagnant, smelly river.\n\nOperations at the port of Porto Alegre have been suspended and its international airport indefinitely closed.\n\nThe Air Force said the military base outside town will receive commercial flights transporting aid and passengers.\n\nIn a rare dry spot in Porto Alegre's historic center, dozens of people gathered around a generator rented by a pharmacy on Wednesday to charge their cell phones.\n\n\"This is a parallel universe,\" said one of them, university professor Daniela da Silva, 30.\n\nThe Inmet meteorological institute has warned of more storms with heavy rains and winds in the south of the state and downpours over the weekend in the Porto Alegre region.\n\nDue to climate change, extreme or rare events \"are becoming more frequent and more extreme,\" Jose Marengo, research coordinator at Brazil's National Center for Natural Disaster Monitoring (Cemaden), told AFP.\n\nThe federal government, meanwhile, said it would import 200,000 tons of rice to guarantee supplies and preempt price speculation. The flooded region supplies more than two-thirds of the rice consumed in Brazil.\n\nUN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres extended his condolences in a statement to the people of Brazil, saying that \"disasters such as this are a reminder of the devastating effects of the climate crisis on lives and livelihoods.\"\n\nRead more:\n\nFloods misery reminder of changing climate's role in supercharging The animal was secured by firemen and loaded into a Zodiac inflatable boat to take it to safety.\n\nThe floods have destroyed infrastructure and bridges, blocking access to Porto Alegre, where supermarket shelves are empty and looting has been reported at night.\n\nGovernor Eduardo Leite said initial calculations indicate that Rio Grande do Sul will need at least 19 billion reais ($3.68 billion) to rebuild from the damage, which has extended into farm areas around the capital.\n\n\"The effect of the floods and the extent of the tragedy are devastating,\" he said on social media.\n\nIn Brasilia, the federal government estimated the fiscal impact of the flooding at 7.7 billion reais ($1.49 billion), mostly due to the injection of funds into a support program for small businesses hit by the floods.\n\n\"This doesn't end here,\" President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva said at an event announcing steps to help the stricken state. {"uri": "8118174937", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:03:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:03:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:02:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.arabnews.com/node/2507021/saudi-arabia", "title": "Saudi king, crown prince offer condolences to Brazilian president", "body": "RIYADH: Saudi Arabia's King Salman sent a message of condolences and sympathy to Brazilain President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, following the floods that swept the state of Rio Grande do Sul that killed and injured several people and left a number missing, the Saudi Press Agency reported on Wednesday.\n\n\"We learned of the news of the floods that swept through the state of Rio Grande do Sul, south of the Federal Republic of Brazil, and the resulting deaths, injuries, and missing persons,\" the king said.\n\nHe added: \"We share Your Excellency's pain of this tragedy, and we send to you, to the families of the deceased, and to your friendly people, our warmest condolences and sincere sympathy, wishing that the missing will return safely and the injured a speedy recovery.\"\n\nCrown Prince Mohammed bin Salman also sent a similar cable to the Brazilian president.\n\nHeavy rains and flooding in the southern state of Rio Grande do Sul since last week also have left 128 people missing, authorities said. {"uri": "8116995110", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "08:46:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T08:46:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T08:45:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/may/08/brazilian-city-rations-water-after-flood/", "title": "Brazilian city rations water after flood", "body": "PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil -- The mayor of a major city in southern Brazil pleaded with residents to comply with his water rationing decree, given that some four-fifths of the population is without running water, a week after major flooding that has left at least 90 people dead and more than 130 others missing.\n\nEfforts were continuing to rescue people stranded by the floods in the southern state of Rio Grande do Sul, as more rains were forecast for the region into next week. The capital, Porto Alegre, has been virtually cut off, with the airport and bus station closed and main roads blocked because of the floodwaters.\n\nThe floods in Brazil are among extreme weather events being seen around the world.\n\nYoga teacher Maria Vit\u00f3ria Jorge's apartment building in downtown Porto Alegre is flooded, so she's leaving it behind, having withdrawn about $1,600 from her savings to rent an apartment for herself and her parents elsewhere in the state.\n\n\"I can't shower at home, wash the dishes or even have drinkable water,\" the 35-year-old Jorge said in her car as she prepared to travel. She had just a gallon of water for the 125-mile drive to the city of Torres, so far unaffected by the floods.\n\nFive of Porto Alegre's six water treatment facilities aren't working, and Porto Alegre Mayor Sebasti\u00e3o Melo on Monday decreed that water be used exclusively for \"essential consumption.\"\n\n\"We are living an unprecedented natural disaster and everyone needs to help,\" Melo told journalists. \"I am getting water trucks to soccer fields and people will have to go there to get their water in bottles. I cannot get them to go home to home.\"\n\nThe most urgent need is drinking water, but food and personal hygiene products are also in short supply. Other Brazilian states are mobilizing trucks with donations bound for Rio Grande do Sul.\n\nThere were long lines and empty shelves at supermarkets in Porto Alegre on Tuesday. Some people have tried to buy bottled water since the weekend, and when they could find it, their purchases were limited to two 1.3-gallon bottles.\n\nPublic health experts say there is also growing risk of disease as much of the region remains submerged, warning that cases of dengue fever and leptospirosis, a bacterial disease, in particular could rise sharply within days.\n\n<span class=\"Object\" id=\"OBJ_PREFIX_DWT168_com_zimbra_url\" role=\"link\" style=\"color: rgb(51, 102, 153); text-decoration-line: none; cursor: pointer;\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Fcd-wSFNN5c\" rel=\"noopener nofollow noopener noreferrer\" style=\"color: rgb(51, 102, 153); cursor: pointer;\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.youtube.com/embed/Fcd-wSFNN5c</a></span>\" title=\"Aerial video of flooding in Brazil\" frameborder=\"O\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\" allowfullscreen>\n\nAdriano Hueck on Tuesday was attempting to retrieve medicine stocked at a friend's warehouse, which is partially flooded.\n\n\"If we can save some of it, there's still a chance it can be useful in hospitals,\" said 53-year-old Hueck, who then pointed toward another part of the city. \"My house is somewhere there. You can't even see its roof now.\"\n\nLike Jorge, the yoga teacher, residents in Rio Grande do Sul who are able to flee are doing so, amid fears of shortage and disease. However, it's difficult for many to leave Porto Alegre with main access roads blocked by floodwaters. The city's airport and main bus terminal are filled with water and closed for the foreseeable future.\n\nClose to the airport, about 100 people of a nearby slum set up tents on the road, hoping to return to their shacks on small boats to try to save some of their belongings.\n\nThe downpour has stopped for now, but a looming cold front was forecast to bring more severe rain starting Tuesday night, mainly in the southern part of the state, according to the National Meteorological Institute. Rainfall could exceed nearly six inches by early Wednesday.\n\nLate Monday, Rio Grande do Sul Gov. Eduardo Leite issued an alert for several cities close to the huge Patos Lagoon. The floodwaters in Porto Alegre and other cities pass through the lagoon to the sea.\n\n\"The water level will rise and it will affect you,\" he said in a video broadcast on his social media channels. \"Please, believe the alerts and help us save lives. Let's reduce the damage so we can be together to rebuild.\"\n\nPeople rest in a shelter after their homes were flooded by heavy rains in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil, Saturday, May 4, 2024. {"uri": "8116544050", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "02:50:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T02:50:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T02:50:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://zeenews.india.com/world/brazil-floods-death-toll-rises-to-90-havoc-leaves-150000-homeless-missing-2747609.html", "title": "Brazil Floods: Death Toll Rises To 90, Havoc Leaves 150,000 Homeless, Missing", "body": "Eldorado Do Sul: Rescuers rushed to evacuate people stranded by devastating floods across the southern Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul on Tuesday, with at least 90 dead, thousands left homeless, and desperate survivors seeking food and basic supplies. On the outskirts of Eldorado do Sul, 17 kilometers (10.5 miles) from the state capital of Porto Alegre, many people were sleeping on the roadside and told Reuters they were going hungry. Entire families were leaving on foot, carrying belongings in backpacks and shopping carts.\n\n\"We've been without food for three days and we've only just got this blanket. I'm with people I don't even know, I don't know where my family is,\" said a young man who gave his name as Ricardo Junior.\n\nThe flooding has hampered rescue efforts, with dozens of people still waiting to be evacated by boat or helicopter from stricken homes. Small boats crisscrossed the flooded town searching for survivors. The state's Civil Defense agency said the death toll had risen to 90 with another four deaths being investigated, while 131 people were still unaccounted for and 155,000 homeless.\n\nThe heavy rains that began last week have caused rivers to flood, inundating whole towns and destroying roads and bridges.Rain is forecast to let up on Thursday but then continue through the weekend.\n\nClimate experts attributed the extreme rainfall in Rio Grande do Sul to the confluence of a heatwave caused by this year's El Ni\u00f1o phenomenon, which warms the waters of the Pacific and brings rain to southern Brazil; a weaker cold front with rain and gales coming from the Antarctic; and unusual warmth in the Atlantic also raising humidity.\n\nGlobal warming exacerbates these phenomena and intensifies the effects between such systems, making weather unpredictable, said Marcelo Schneider, a National Meteorology Institute (Inmet) researcher.\n\nELECTRICITY CUTS\n\nIn Porto Alegre, a city of 1.3 million inhabitants, downtown streets were under water after the Guaiba River breached its banks with record water levels.\n\nPorto Alegre residents faced empty supermarket shelves and closed gas stations, with shops rationing sales of mineral water. The city distributed water in trucks to hospitals and shelters.\n\nThe floods have also impacted water and electricity services, with more than 1.4 million affected overall, according to Civil Defense. Almost half a million people were without power in Porto Alegre and outlying towns as electricity companies cut off supplies for security reasons in flooded neighborhoods. National grid operator ONS said five hydroelectric dams and transmission lines were shut down due to the heavy rains. The city's airport, its apron under water, has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nFuel shortages were reported as state-run oil company Petrobras said it was having trouble moving diesel from its refinery in badly-flooded Canoas within metropolitan Porto Alegre, a senior government official said.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva said on a government television program that the extent of the damage will not be known until the waters subside. He promised federal aid for the state in what is considered its worst ever climate disaster.\n\nJP Morgan economists projected that the impact of the floods on Brazil's economy would be a modest dent in GDP growth and a marginal increase in inflation, mainly due to higher prices for rice that is largely produced in Rio Grande do Sul. The government said Brazil will import rice to stabilize the market.\n\nBesides destroying critical infrastructure, the heavy rains and flooding have left grains fields under water and killed livestock, interrupting the soy harvest and halting work at multiple meat plants.\n\nThe Rio Grande port, a major port for grain exports, was operating normally, the state's port authority said. However, main access roads were impassable, disrupting grain deliveries to the port as trucks had to make a wide detour, exporters said.", "source": {"uri": "zeenews.india.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8112885337", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "23:01:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T23:01:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T23:00:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/news/natural-disasters/death-toll-mounts-after-heavy-rain-flooding-in-brazil-c-14560865", "title": "Death toll mounts after heavy rain, flooding in Brazil", "body": "Death toll mounts after heavy rain, flooding in BrazilStaff WritersReutersMon, 6 May 2024 6:54AM\n\nThe death toll from heavy rains that have caused flooding in Brazil's southern state of Rio Grande do Sul has risen to at least 78, local authorities say, with more than 115,000 people displaced.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva arrived in Rio Grande do Sul on Sunday morning with most members of his cabinet to discuss rescue and reconstruction works with local authorities.\n\n\"Bureaucracy will not stand in our way, stopping us from recovering the state's greatness,\" Lula said at a press conference.\n\n\"It is a war scenario, and will need post-war measures,\" state governor Eduardo Leite added.\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nThe death toll could still substantially increase as 105 people were reported missing on Sunday, up from about 70 the prior day, according to the state civil defence authority. It also said it was investigating whether another four deaths were related to the storms.\n\nFlooding from storms in the past few days has affected more than two thirds of the nearly 500 cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina, leaving more than 115,000 people displaced, according to authorities.\n\nFloods have destroyed roads and bridges in several cities. The rains also triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nMore than 400,000 people were without power on Sunday evening, while nearly a third of the state's population was without water, authorities said.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the state capital, the Guaiba lake breached its banks, hitting the highest water level on records, according to the national geological service. Porto Alegre's international airport has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nIn the city of Canoas near Porto Alegre, Julio Manichesque, 76, was rescued by volunteers after he had stayed since Friday on the roof of the house where he has lived for 52 years.\n\n\"I have never seen that much water,\" Manichesque said.\n\nMany volunteers also have been risking their own safety during the rescue efforts, using small boats, jet skis and kayaks.\n\nFabiano Saldanha, 30, said he and three friends have used jet skis to rescue about 50 people since Friday in islands that are part of Porto Flooding from storms in the past few days has affected more than two thirds of the nearly 500 cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina, leaving more than 115,000 people displaced, according to authorities.\n\nThe death toll from heavy rains that have caused flooding in Brazil's southern state of Rio Grande do Sul has risen to at least 78, local authorities said on Sunday, with more than 115,000 people displaced.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva arrived in Rio Grande do Sul on Sunday morning with most members of his cabinet to discuss rescue and reconstruction works with local authorities. \"Bureaucracy will not stand in our way, stopping us from recovering the state's greatness,\" Lula said at a press conference.\n\n\"It is a war scenario, and will need post-war measures,\" state governor Eduardo Leite added. The death toll could still substantially increase as 105 people were reported missing on Sunday, up from about 70 the prior day, according to the state civil defense authority. It also said it was investigating whether another four deaths were related to the storms.\n\nFlooding from storms in the past few days has affected more than two thirds of the nearly 500 cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina, leaving more than 115,000 people displaced, according to authorities. Floods have destroyed roads and bridges in several cities. The rains also triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nMore than 400,000 people were without power on Sunday evening, while nearly a third of the state's population was without water, authorities said. In Porto Alegre, the state capital, the Guaiba lake breached its banks, hitting the highest water level on records, according to the national geological service. Porto Alegre's international airport has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nIn the city of Canoas, near Porto Alegre, Julio Manichesque, 76, was rescued by volunteers after he had stayed since Friday on the roof of the house where he has lived for 52 years. \"I have never seen that much water,\" Manichesque said.\n\nMany volunteers also have been risking their own safety during the rescue efforts, using small boats, jet skis and kayaks. Fabiano Saldanha, 30, said he and three friends have used jet skis to rescue about 50 people since Friday in islands that are part of Porto Alegre.\n\n\"The only thing we hear when we enter a street is 'help,' 'help,'\" Saldanha said. {"uri": "2024-05-349583812", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:19:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:19:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:19:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://globalnation.inquirer.net/235172/brazil-flooding-death-toll-surpasses-100", "title": "Brazil flooding death toll surpasses 100", "body": "Porto Alegre, Brazil -- The death toll from devastating floods that have ravaged southern Brazil for days surpassed 100 on Wednesday, authorities said, as the search for dozens of missing people was interrupted by fresh storms.\n\nSome 400 municipalities have been affected by the worst natural calamity ever to hit the state of Rio Grande do Sul, with hundreds of people injured and more than 160,000 forced from their homes.\n\nMany have no access to drinking water or electricity -- or even the means to call for help, with telephone and internet services down in many places.\n\nREAD: Brazilians queue for precious water as flood damage intensifies\n\nOn Tuesday, state governor Eduardo Leite had warned the human toll was likely to rise as \"the emergency is continuing to develop\" in the state capital of Porto Alegre and other cities and towns.\n\nSome 15,000 soldiers, firefighters, police and volunteers were at work across the state, many in boats and jet skis, to rescue those trapped and transport aid.\n\nBut in Porto Alegre the rains returned on Wednesday, halting evacuation efforts.\n\nThe mayor's office urged rescue boats to suspend their activities, citing the risk of electric shocks from lightning and strong winds of over 80 kilometers (50 miles) per hour.\n\nAuthorities urged people not to return to affected areas due to possible landslide and health hazards.\n\n\"Contaminated water can transmit diseases,\" civil defense spokeswoman Sabrina Ribas warned on Wednesday.\n\nMany people have been loath to leave their homes for the safety of shelters amid reports of abandoned properties being looted.\n\nThe National Confederation of Municipalities said about 61,000 homes -- down from an earlier estimate of 100,000 -- had been damaged or destroyed by unprecedented rains and floods in the state, with losses estimated at about 6.3 billion reais (some $1.2 billion.)\n\nDamage to schools, hospitals and municipal buildings amounted to about $69 million.\n\nREAD: No letup yet for flood-battered southern Brazil\n\nPorto Alegre is home to about 1.4 million people and the larger metropolitan area has more than double that number.\n\nThe state's Guaiba River, which runs through Porto Alegre, reached historic levels and five dams are at risk of rupturing, with two of them in \"imminent\" danger.\n\n'A parallel universe'\n\nThere were queues at public taps and wells as officials warned that the most urgent need for people stranded by impassable roads, collapsed bridges and flooded homes was drinking water.\n\nOnly two of Porto Alegre's six water treatment plants were functioning, the mayor's office said Tuesday, and hospitals and shelters were being supplied by tankers.\n\nHelicopters were delivering water and food to communities most in need, while work continued on restoring road access.\n\nThe Brazilian Navy was to send its \"Atlantic\" vessel -- Latin America's largest -- to Rio Grande do Sul on Wednesday with two mobile water treatment stations.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has vowed there would be \"no lack of resources to meet the needs of Rio Grande do Sul.\"\n\nIn Gasometro, a part of Porto Alegre popular with tourists, the water continued to rise Wednesday, complicating rescue efforts.\n\n\"You can only cross on foot or by boat. There is no other way,\" 30-year-old resident Luan Pas told AFP next to a street turned into a stagnant, smelly river.\n\nOperations at the port of Porto Alegre have been suspended and its international airport indefinitely closed.\n\nThe Air Force said the military base outside town will receive commercial flights transporting aid and passengers.\n\nIn a rare dry spot in Porto Alegre's historic center, dozens of people gathered around a generator rented by a pharmacy on Wednesday to charge their cell phones.\n\n\"This is a parallel universe,\" said one of them, university professor Daniela da Silva, 30.\n\nThe Inmet meteorological institute has warned of more storms with heavy rains and winds in the south of the state and downpours over the weekend in the Porto Alegre region.\n\nDue to climate change, extreme or rare events \"are becoming more frequent and more extreme,\" Jose Marengo, research coordinator at Brazil's National Center for Natural Disaster Monitoring (Cemaden), told AFP.\n\nThe federal government, meanwhile, said it would import 200,000 tons of rice to guarantee supplies and preempt price speculation. The flooded region supplies more than two-thirds of the rice consumed in Brazil.\n\nUN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres extended his condolences in a statement to the people of Brazil, saying that \"disasters such as this are a reminder of the devastating effects of the climate crisis on lives and livelihoods.\"", "source": {"uri": "globalnation.inquirer.net", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8116396389", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "23:43:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T23:43:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T23:43:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.perthnow.com.au/news/natural-disasters/brazil-floods-displace-150000-scores-dead-or-missing-c-14586349", "title": "Brazil floods displace 150,000, scores dead or missing", "body": "Rescuers have rushed to evacuate people stranded by devastating floods across the southern Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul with at least 90 dead, thousands left homeless and desperate survivors seeking food and basic supplies.\n\nOn the outskirts of Eldorado do Sul, 17km from the state capital of Porto Alegre, many people were sleeping on the roadside and told Reuters they were going hungry. Entire families were leaving on foot, carrying belongings in backpacks and shopping carts.\n\n\"We've been without food for three days and we've only just got this blanket. I'm with people I don't even know, I don't know where my family is,\" said a young man on Tuesday who gave his name as Ricardo Junior.\n\nThe flooding has hampered rescue efforts, with dozens of people still waiting to be evacuated by boat or helicopter from stricken homes. Small boats crisscrossed the flooded town searching for survivors.\n\nThe state's Civil Defense agency said the death toll had risen to 90 with another four deaths being investigated, while 131 people were still unaccounted for and 155,000 homeless.\n\nThe heavy rains that began last week have caused rivers to flood, inundating whole towns and destroying roads and bridges.\n\nRain is forecast to let up on Thursday but then continue through the weekend.\n\nClimate experts attributed the extreme rainfall in Rio Grande do Sul to the confluence of a heatwave caused by this year's El Nino phenomenon, which warms the waters of the Pacific and brings rain to southern Brazil, a weaker cold front with rain and gales coming from the Antarctic, and unusual warmth in the Atlantic also raising humidity.\n\nGlobal warming exacerbates these phenomena and intensifies the effects between such systems, making weather unpredictable, said Marcelo Schneider, a National Meteorology Institute (Inmet) researcher.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, a city of 1.3 million inhabitants, downtown streets were under water after the Guaiba River breached its banks with record water levels.\n\nPorto Alegre residents faced empty supermarket shelves and closed gas stations, with shops rationing sales of mineral water. The city distributed water in trucks to hospitals and shelters.\n\nThe floods have also impacted water and electricity services, with more than 1.4 million affected overall, according to Civil Defense.\n\nAlmost half a million people were without power in Porto Alegre and outlying towns as electricity companies cut off supplies for security reasons in flooded neighbourhoods.\n\nNational grid operator ONS said five hydroelectric dams and transmission lines were shut down due to the heavy rains.\n\nThe city's airport, its apron under water, has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nFuel shortages were reported as state-run oil company Petrobras said it was having trouble moving diesel from its refinery in badly flooded Canoas within metropolitan Porto Alegre, a senior government official said.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva said on a government TV program that the extent of the damage will not be known until the waters subside. He promised federal aid for the state in what is considered its worst ever climate disaster.\n\nJP Morgan economists projected that the impact of the floods on Brazil's economy would be a modest dent in GDP growth and a marginal increase in inflation, mainly due to higher prices for rice that is largely produced in Rio Grande do Sul. The government said Brazil will import rice to stabilise the market.\n\nBesides destroying critical infrastructure, the heavy rains and flooding have left grains fields under water and killed livestock, interrupting the soy harvest and halting work at multiple meat plants.\n\nThe Rio Grande port, a major port for grain exports, was operating normally, the state's port authority said. However, main access roads were impassable, disrupting grain deliveries to the port as trucks had to make a wide detour, exporters said.", "source": {"uri": "perthnow.com.au", "dataType": "news", It was investigating whether another six deaths were related to the storms, it added.\n\nStorms in the past few days have affected about two thirds of the nearly 500 towns and cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina. {"uri": "8118885202", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:50:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:50:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T09:49:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.chinadaily.com.cn/a/202405/09/WS663c94f6a31082fc043c63b5.html", "title": "Torrential rains and floods displace 156,000 people in southern Brazil", "body": "Southern Brazil is reeling from massive floods caused by days of heavy rainfall, with the natural disaster causing unprecedented devastation and leaving the region struggling to cope. Observers say the true impact of the floods that have displaced more than 156,000 people and affected more than 1.3 million is not likely to be known for weeks.\n\nThe floods have wreaked havoc across nearly 350 out of 497 cities in the state of Rio Grande do Sul, critically damaging infrastructure, including roads, bridges and causing the partial collapse of a dam at a hydroelectric plant. More than 100 people are known to have been killed and at least 131 are still missing, according to information from the civil defense force involved in disaster relief.\n\nPresident Inacio Lula da Silva, commonly known as Lula, declared a state of emergency, echoing the sentiments of Rio Grande do Sul Governor Eduardo Leite, who ominously predicted a substantial rise in the death toll as rescue missions expand their reach, and said the \"scenes are out of a war\", in comments over the weekend.\n\n\"We ... knew that heavy and intense rains would come, but we never imagined this magnitude,\" Marcelo Schneider, a meteorologist and district coordinator for Meteorology for southern Brazil at the National Institute of Meteorology (Inmet), told China Daily.\n\n\"The warnings were there,\" Schneider said. \"One of the main factors is the intersection of two events: the El Nino and La Nina phenomena.\"\n\nWhile heavy rain is not unusual in this part of Brazil, the sheer amount that fell over the past few days has been historic.\n\nInmet first alerted about upcoming heavy rains on April 26, warning of 100 mm of rain over the following weekend and winds in excess of 70 km/h. MetSul Meteorologica, a meteorological monitoring entity, also warned of severe risks of flooding. In the last few days of the month, the state received roughly 70 percent of the rain it usually receives in whole month, and the downpours continued into May.\n\n\"Despite improvements in parts of the state, some areas will remain under severe conditions for a very long time,\" MetSul said in a statement, noting that the waters had changed the urban landscape of Porto Alegre, the largest city in the Rio Grande do Sul state.\n\nInmet warned this week that rains would continue in the southernmost part of the state, with the downpour likely to exceed 150 mm by the morning of April 8 in some areas.\n\nAuthorities are now worried about drinking water running out.\n\nIt may have been \"the worst meteorological catastrophe\" in the state's history, said Paulo Pimenta, Lula's press secretary.\n\nRobson Cardoch Valdez, an economist and professor of international relations at the Brazilian Institute of Education, Development and Research, said the ramifications of this natural disaster extend beyond the immediate threat to lives.\n\nValdez, who works as an advisor to the Rio Grande do Sul government, suggested that the economic tremors of the devastation could ripple through the country for years, particularly in sectors like agriculture and oil production.\n\nThe floods have disrupted business operations, with some airports suspending flights and train services also disrupted. The extensive damage to infrastructure means a laborious and costly road to recovery.\n\n\"Once the water recedes, it will be possible to have a more specific (idea) of the economic impact of the rain, but ... at this moment we are only working with estimates ... to assist in everything necessary to rebuild the physical structure of Rio Grande do Sul,\" Valdez told China Daily.\n\nThe rebuilding could take some time. More rain is expected in the coming days and could get heavy again between May 10 and 15, according to MetSul.\n\nAdding to the complexity of the recovery, Rio Grande do Sul, a key agricultural hub, is bracing for a spike in the prices of staple crops and potential inflationary pressures on food products as a result of the floods.\n\nValdez highlighted the anticipated impact on agriculture, an industry critical to Rio Grande do Sul state and Brazil as a whole. The floods will likely impact crop production and livestock rearing and are expected to lead to an uptick in the prices of rice, corn, tomatoes and beef, among other staples.\n\nThe expected inflation, coupled with the costs associated with the extensive rebuilding of the state's physical infrastructure, presents a multifaceted challenge for federal and state authorities.\n\nThe massive floods came just seven months after an extratropical cyclone hit the region with heavy rains that caused floods and killed dozens.", "source": {"uri": "chinadaily.com.cn", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8116299094", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "21:52:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T21:52:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T21:50:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.investing.com/news/world-news/brazil-floods-leave-150000-homeless-scores-dead-or-missing-3426084", "title": "Brazil floods leave 150,000 homeless, scores dead or missing By Reuters", "body": "ELDORADO DO SUL, Brazil (Reuters) -Rescuers rushed to evacuate people stranded by devastating floods across the southern Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul on Tuesday, with at least 90 dead, thousands left homeless, and desperate survivors seeking food and basic supplies.\n\nOn the outskirts of Eldorado do Sul, 17 kilometers (10.5 miles) from the state capital of Porto Alegre, many people were sleeping on the roadside and told Reuters they were going hungry. Entire families were leaving on foot, carrying belongings in backpacks and shopping carts.\n\n\"We've been without food for three days and we've only just got this blanket. I'm with people I don't even know, I don't know where my family is,\" said a young man who gave his name as Ricardo Junior.\n\nThe flooding has hampered rescue efforts, with dozens of people still waiting to be evacuated by boat or helicopter from stricken homes. Small boats crisscrossed the flooded town searching for survivors.\n\nThe state's Civil Defense agency said the death toll had risen to 90 with another four deaths being investigated, while 131 people were still unaccounted for and 155,000 homeless.\n\nThe heavy rains that began last week have caused rivers to flood, inundating whole towns and destroying roads and bridges.\n\nRain is forecast to let up on Thursday but then continue through the weekend.\n\nClimate experts attributed the extreme rainfall in Rio Grande do Sul to the confluence of a heatwave caused by this year's El Ni\u00f1o phenomenon, which warms the waters of the Pacific and brings rain to southern Brazil; a weaker cold front with rain and gales coming from the Antarctic; and unusual warmth in the Atlantic also raising humidity.\n\nGlobal warming exacerbates these phenomena and intensifies the effects between such systems, making weather unpredictable, said Marcelo Schneider, a National Meteorology Institute (Inmet) researcher.\n\nELECTRICITY CUTS\n\nIn Porto Alegre, a city of 1.3 million inhabitants, downtown streets were under water after the Guaiba River breached its banks with record water levels.\n\nPorto Alegre residents faced empty supermarket shelves and closed gas stations, with shops rationing sales of mineral water. The city distributed water in trucks to hospitals and shelters.\n\nThe floods have also impacted water and electricity services, with more than 1.4 million affected overall, according to Civil Defense.\n\nAlmost half a million people were without power in Porto Alegre and outlying towns as electricity companies cut off supplies for security reasons in flooded neighborhoods. National grid operator ONS said five hydroelectric dams and transmission lines were shut down due to the heavy rains.\n\nThe city's airport, its apron under water, has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nFuel shortages were reported as state-run oil company Petrobras said it was having trouble moving diesel from its refinery in badly-flooded Canoas within metropolitan Porto Alegre, a senior government official said.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva said on a government television program that the extent of the damage will not be known until the waters subside. He promised federal aid for the state in what is considered its worst ever climate disaster.\n\nJP Morgan economists projected that the impact of the floods on Brazil's economy would be a modest dent in GDP growth and a marginal increase in inflation, mainly due to higher prices for rice that is largely produced in Rio Grande do Sul. The government said Brazil will import rice to stabilize the market.\n\nBesides destroying critical infrastructure, the heavy rains and flooding have left grains fields under water and killed livestock, interrupting the soy harvest and halting work at multiple meat plants.\n\nThe Rio Grande port, a major port for grain exports, was operating normally, the state's port authority said. However, main access roads were impassable, disrupting grain deliveries to the port as trucks had to make a wide detour, exporters said.", "source": {"uri": "investing.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8116577907", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "03:28:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T03:28:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T03:27:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/brazilians-queue-for-precious-water-as-flood-1822626.html", "title": "Brazilians Queue For Precious Water As Flood Damage Intensifies - UrduPoint", "body": "Porto Alegre, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 8th May, 2024) Teams scurried on Tuesday to deliver humanitarian aid in Porto Alegre and other flood-ravaged municipalities in southern Brazil, where queues formed for drinking water as forecasters warned of more downpours.\n\nThe worst natural calamity ever to hit the state of Rio Grande do Sul has claimed at least 90 lives, with 362 people reported injured and 131 still missing, according to the civil defense force that handles disaster relief.\n\nNearly 400 municipalities have been hit, including state capital Porto Alegre, and more than 156,000 people have been forced to leave their homes as streets were transformed into rivers after days of record-breaking rain.\n\nPorto Alegre is home to some 1.4 million people and the larger metropolitan area has more than double that number.\n\nFor tens of thousands of people stranded by impassable roads, collapsed bridges and flooded homes in Rio Grande do Sul, \"the most urgent demand is (drinking) water,\" said civil defense official Sabrina Ribas.\n\n\"This is horrible. We have children,\" said 27-year-old Gabriela Almeida, queuing at a public tap with a one-year-old in her arms.\n\nIndividuals and businesses with wells were doing what they could to help.\n\nAlvorada resident Benildo Carvalho, 48, was one of them -- filling neighbors' bottles with a hose as a line of people started to form outside his house.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva said more emergency funds would be freed up Tuesday, vowing there would be \"no lack of resources to meet the needs of Rio Grande do Sul.\"\n\nSome 15,000 soldiers, firefighters, police and volunteers were hard at work in planes and boats, even jet skis, to rescue those trapped and transport aid.\n\nBrazil's neighbors Uruguay and Argentina have sent rescue equipment and trained personnel.\n\nCelebrities were also doing their part. Footballer Neymar sent a plane with donations and said on Instagram he was \"praying for everything to return to normal.\"\n\nAs the calamity showed no signs of abating, weather forecasts suggested it could still get worse.\n\nThe Inmet meteorological institute warned of possible storms in the south of Rio Grande do Sul until Wednesday, followed by rainfall in the center and north which it said would imperil the rescue effort.\n\nThe state's Guaiba River, which runs through Porto Alegre, remained at historic high levels Tuesday, and officials said five dams were at risk of rupturing.\n\nAccording to weather agency MetSul, the flooding has \"changed the map of the metropolitan region\" of Porto Alegre.\n\nLula warned that if harvests are delayed by the flooding in this deeply agricultural region, the country \"will have to import rice and beans.\"\n\nPolice, meanwhile, said there have been reports of evacuated homes being looted and some residents, afraid of such intrusions, were refusing to move to shelters.", "source": {"uri": "urdupoint.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UrduPoint"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8118210803", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:49:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:49:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:48:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.malaymail.com/news/world/2024/05/09/brazil-flooding-death-toll-surpasses-100/133309", "title": "Brazil flooding death toll surpasses 100", "body": "PORTO ALEGRE, May 9 -- The death toll from devastating floods that have ravaged southern Brazil for days surpassed 100 on Wednesday, authorities said, as the search for dozens of missing people was interrupted by fresh storms.\n\nSome 400 municipalities have been affected by the worst natural calamity ever to hit the state of Rio Grande do Sul, with hundreds of people injured and more than 160,000 forced from their homes.\n\nMany have no access to drinking water or electricity -- or even the means to call for help, with telephone and internet services down in many places.\n\nOn Tuesday, state governor Eduardo Leite had warned the human toll was likely to rise as \"the emergency is continuing to develop\" in the state capital of Porto Alegre and other cities and towns.\n\nSome 15,000 soldiers, firefighters, police and volunteers were at work across the state, many in boats and jet skis, to rescue those trapped and transport aid.\n\nBut in Porto Alegre the rains returned on Wednesday, halting evacuation efforts.\n\nThe mayor's office urged rescue boats to suspend their activities, citing the risk of electric shocks from lightning and strong winds of over 80 kilometres per hour.\n\nAuthorities urged people not to return to affected areas due to possible landslide and health hazards.\n\n\"Contaminated water can transmit diseases,\" civil defence spokeswoman Sabrina Ribas warned on Wednesday.\n\nMany people have been loath to leave their homes for the safety of shelters amid reports of abandoned properties being looted.\n\nThe National Confederation of Municipalities said about 61,000 homes -- down from an earlier estimate of 100,000 -- had been damaged or destroyed by unprecedented rains and floods in the state, with losses estimated at about 6.3 billion reais (some RM5.8 billion.)\n\nDamage to schools, hospitals and municipal buildings amounted to about 351 million reais.\n\nPorto Alegre is home to about 1.4 million people and the larger metropolitan area has more than double that number.\n\nThe state's Guaiba River, which runs through Porto Alegre, reached historic levels and five dams are at risk of rupturing, with two of them in \"imminent\" danger.\n\nThere were queues at public taps and wells as officials warned that the most urgent need for people stranded by impassable roads, collapsed bridges and flooded homes was drinking water.\n\nOnly two of Porto Alegre's six water treatment plants were functioning, the mayor's office said Tuesday, and hospitals and shelters were being supplied by tankers.\n\nHelicopters were delivering water and food to communities most in need, while work continued on restoring road access.\n\nThe Brazilian Navy was to send its \"Atlantic\" vessel -- Latin America's largest -- to Rio Grande do Sul on Wednesday with two mobile water treatment stations.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has vowed there would be \"no lack of resources to meet the needs of Rio Grande do Sul.\"\n\nIn Gasometro, a part of Porto Alegre popular with tourists, the water continued to rise Wednesday, complicating rescue efforts.\n\n\"You can only cross on foot or by boat. There is no other way,\" 30-year-old resident Luan Pas told AFP next to a street turned into a stagnant, smelly river.\n\nOperations at the port of Porto Alegre have been suspended and its international airport indefinitely closed.\n\nThe Air Force said the military base outside town will receive commercial flights transporting aid and passengers.\n\nIn a rare dry spot in Porto Alegre's historic centre, dozens of people gathered around a generator rented by a pharmacy on Wednesday to charge their cell phones.\n\n\"This is a parallel universe,\" said one of them, university professor Daniela da Silva, 30.\n\nThe Inmet meteorological institute has warned of more storms with heavy rains and winds in the south of the state and downpours over the weekend in the Porto Alegre region.\n\nDue to climate change, extreme or rare events \"are becoming more frequent and more extreme,\" Jose Marengo, research coordinator at Brazil's National Centre for Natural Disaster Monitoring (Cemaden), told AFP.\n\nThe federal government, meanwhile, said it would import 200,000 tons of rice to guarantee supplies and preempt price speculation. The flooded region supplies more than two-thirds of the rice consumed in Brazil.\n\nUN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres extended his condolences in a statement to the people of Brazil, saying that \"disasters such as this are a reminder of the devastating effects of the climate crisis on lives and livelihoods\". -- AFP", "source": {"uri": "malaymail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Malay {"uri": "8117018507", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "09:01:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T09:01:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T09:00:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/582684", "title": "Brazil floods leave 150,000 homeless, scores dead or missing", "body": "ELDORADO DO SUL, Brazil - Rescuers rushed to evacuate people stranded by devastating floods across the southern Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul on Tuesday, with at least 90 dead, thousands left homeless, and desperate survivors seeking food and basic supplies.\n\nOn the outskirts of Eldorado do Sul, 17 kilometers from the state capital of Porto Alegre, many people were sleeping on the roadside and told Reuters they were going hungry. Entire families were leaving on foot, carrying belongings in backpacks and shopping carts.\n\n\"We've been without food for three days and we've only just got this blanket. I'm with people I don't even know, I don't know where my family is,\" said a young man who gave his name as Ricardo Junior.\n\nThe state's Civil Defense agency said the death toll had risen to 90 with another four deaths being investigated, while 131 people were still unaccounted for and 155,000 homeless\n\nThe flooding has hampered rescue efforts, with dozens of people still waiting to be evacuated by boat or helicopter from stricken homes. Small boats crisscrossed the flooded town searching for survivors.\n\nALSO READ: Brazil floods: Lula seeks state of emergency after 85 dead\n\nThe state's Civil Defense agency said the death toll had risen to 90 with another four deaths being investigated, while 131 people were still unaccounted for and 155,000 homeless.\n\nThe heavy rains that began last week have caused rivers to flood, inundating whole towns and destroying roads and bridges.\n\nRain is forecast to let up on Thursday but then continue through the weekend.\n\nClimate experts attributed the extreme rainfall in Rio Grande do Sul to the confluence of a heatwave caused by this year's El Ni\u00f1o phenomenon, which warms the waters of the Pacific and brings rain to southern Brazil; a weaker cold front with rain and gales coming from the Antarctic; and unusual warmth in the Atlantic also raising humidity.\n\nGlobal warming exacerbates these phenomena and intensifies the effects between such systems, making weather unpredictable, said Marcelo Schneider, a National Meteorology Institute (Inmet) researcher.\n\nElectricity cuts\n\nIn Porto Alegre, a city of 1.3 million inhabitants, downtown streets were underwater after the Guaiba River breached its banks with record water levels.\n\nREAD MORE: Death toll from southern Brazil rainfall rises to 78, many still missing\n\nPorto Alegre residents faced empty supermarket shelves and closed gas stations, with shops rationing sales of mineral water. The city distributed water in trucks to hospitals and shelters.\n\nThe floods have also impacted water and electricity services, with more than 1.4 million affected overall, according to Civil Defense.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva said on a government television program that the extent of the damage will not be known until the waters subside\n\nAlmost half a million people were without power in Porto Alegre and outlying towns as electricity companies cut off supplies for security reasons in flooded neighborhoods. National grid operator ONS said five hydroelectric dams and transmission lines were shut down due to the heavy rains.\n\nThe city's airport, its apron underwater, has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nFuel shortages were reported as state-run oil company Petrobras said it was having trouble moving diesel from its refinery in badly-flooded Canoas within metropolitan Porto Alegre, a senior government official said.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva said on a government television program that the extent of the damage will not be known until the waters subside. He promised federal aid for the state in what is considered its worst-ever climate disaster.\n\nREAD MORE: Toll of Kenya's floods climbs to 228, tropical Cyclone Hidaya weakens after landfall\n\nJP Morgan economists projected that the impact of the floods on Brazil's economy would be a modest dent in GDP growth and a marginal increase in inflation, mainly due to higher prices for rice that is largely produced in Rio Grande do Sul. The government said Brazil will import rice to stabilize the market.\n\nBesides destroying critical infrastructure, the heavy rains and flooding have left grains fields under water and killed livestock, interrupting the soy harvest and halting work at multiple meat plants.\n\nThe Rio Grande port, a major port for grain exports, was operating normally, the state's port authority said. However, main access roads were impassable, disrupting grain deliveries to the port as trucks had to make a wide detour, exporters said.", "source": {"uri": "chinadailyasia.com", "dataType": "news", In the state capital Porto Alegre, Fabiano Saldanha said he and three friends have used jet skis to save about 50 people from flood waters since Friday in islands that are part of the city.\n\n\"The only thing we hear when we enter a street is 'help,' 'help,'\" Saldanha said.\n\nThe death toll could still substantially increase as 105 people were reported missing on Sunday, up from about 70 the prior day, according to the state civil defense authority. It also said it was investigating whether another four deaths were related to the storms.\n\nFlooding from storms in the past few days has affected more than two thirds of the nearly 500 cities in the state, which borders Uruguay and Argentina, leaving more than 115,000 people displaced, according to authorities.\n\nFloods have destroyed roads and bridges in several cities. The rains also triggered landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nMore than 400,000 people were without power on Sunday evening, while nearly a third of the state's population was without water, authorities said.\n\nIn Porto Alegre, the Guaiba lake breached its banks, hitting the highest water level on record, according to the national geological service. Porto Alegre's international airport has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nAt a makeshift rescue center in Porto Alegre, Kaeli Moraes described being rescued along with her husband and their three children when the water had nearly reached the second floor of their house.\n\n\"There was flooding in September, then in November, and now this one. It is only getting worse,\" Moraes said.\n\nIn the city of Canoas, near Porto Alegre, Julio Manichesque, 76, was rescued by volunteers after he had stayed since Friday on the roof of the house where he has lived for 52 years.\n\n\"I have never seen that much water,\" Manichesque said.\n\nDuring his weekly address to crowds in St. Peter's Square in Vatican City, Pope Francis said on Sunday he was {"uri": "2024-05-349512393", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "21:20:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T21:20:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T21:12:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/brazil-flooding-death-toll-reaches-164933103.html", "title": "Brazil flooding death toll surpasses 100", "body": "The death toll from devastating floods that have ravaged southern Brazil for days surpassed 100 on Wednesday, authorities said, as the search for dozens of missing people was interrupted by fresh storms.\n\nSome 400 municipalities have been affected by the worst natural calamity ever to hit the state of Rio Grande do Sul, with hundreds of people injured and 160,000 forced from their homes.\n\nMany have no access to drinking water or electricity -- or even the means to call for help with telephone and internet services down in many places.\n\nOn Tuesday, state governor Eduardo Leite had warned the human toll was likely to rise as \"the emergency is continuing to develop\" in the state capital of Porto Alegre and other cities and towns.\n\nSome 15,000 soldiers, firefighters, police and volunteers were at work across the state, many in boats, and even jet skis, to rescue those trapped and transport aid.\n\nBut in Porto Alegre, the rains returned Wednesday, halting evacuation efforts.\n\nThe mayor's office urged rescue boats to suspend their activities, citing the risk of electric shocks from lightning, and strong winds over 80 kilometers (about 50 miles) per hour.\n\nAuthorities urged people not to return to affected areas due to possible landslide and health hazards.\n\nMany people have been loath to leave their homes for the safety of shelters amid reports of abandoned properties being looted.\n\n\"Contaminated water can transmit diseases,\" civil defense spokeswoman Sabrina Ribas warned on Wednesday.\n\nThe National Confederation of Municipalities said nearly 100,000 homes had been damaged or destroyed by unprecedented rains and floods in the state, with losses estimated at about 4.6 billion reais (more than $900 million.)\n\nPorto Alegre is home to about 1.4 million people and the larger metropolitan area has more than double that number.\n\nThe state's Guaiba River, which runs through Porto Alegre, reached historic levels and five dams are at risk of rupturing.\n\n- 'A parallel universe' -\n\nThere were queues at public taps and wells as officials warned that the most urgent need of people stranded by impassable roads, collapsed bridges and flooded homes was drinking water.\n\nOnly two of Porto Alegre's six water treatment plants were functioning, the mayor's office said Tuesday, and hospitals and shelters were being supplied by tankers.\n\nHelicopters were delivering water and food to communities most in need, while work continued on restoring road access.\n\nThe Brazilian Navy was to send its \"Atlantic\" vessel -- Latin America's largest -- to Rio Grande do Sul on Wednesday with two mobile water treatment stations.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has vowed there would be \"no lack of resources to meet the needs of Rio Grande do Sul.\"\n\nIn Gasometro, a part of Porto Alegre popular with tourists, the water continued to rise Wednesday, complicating rescue efforts.\n\n\"You can only cross on foot or by boat. There is no other way,\" 30-year-old resident Luan Pas told AFP next to a street turned into a stagnant, smelly river.\n\nOperations at the port of Porto Alegre have been suspended, and its international airport indefinitely closed.\n\nThe Air Force said the military base outside town will receive commercial flights transporting aid and passengers.\n\nIn a rare dry spot in Porto Alegre's historic center, dozens of people gathered around a generator rented by a pharmacy on Wednesday to charge their cell phones.\n\n\"This is a parallel universe,\" said one of them, university professor Daniela da Silva, 30.\n\nThe Inmet meteorological institute has warned of more storms with heavy rains and winds in the south of the state and downpours over the weekend in the Porto Alegre region.\n\nThe World Meteorological Organization in a report Wednesday, said Latin America and the Caribbean had recorded its warmest year on record in 2023 -- \"a year of record climatic hazards\" for the region due to climate change and the El Nino weather phenomenon.\n\nMany towns and cities in Brazil, it said, were hit by \"exceptional rainfall\" that caused displacement and massive upheavals.\n\nDue to climate change, extreme or rare events \"are becoming more frequent and more extreme,\" Jose Marengo, research coordinator at Brazil's National Center for Natural Disaster Monitoring (Cemaden), told AFP.\n\nAccording to weather agency MetSul, the flooding has \"changed the map of the metropolitan region\" of Porto Alegre.", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", Flooding from storms have destroyed roads and bridges in several cities, while triggering landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nState Governor Eduardo Leite has emphasized that the death toll should still substantially increase as rescue workers gain access to more regions. Rio Grande do Sul's civil defense said 111 people were still missing, a number that has also been increasing in the last few days. Aljazeera\n\nThe death toll from tremendous flooding in southern Brazil has reached 100, the local civil defence agency said, as emergency crews continued to search for dozens of missing people.\n\nNearly 400 municipalities have been affected after days of heavy rains swamped the Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul.\n\nThe floodwaters injured hundreds of people and forced 160,000 others from their homes as of Wednesday, while the state civil defence authority said 128 people were still missing.\n\nBrazil's national centre for natural disasters said the southern part of the state was under \"high risk\" of more floods throughout the day.\n\nIt said rainfall was expected to restart, and although it was not expected to be significant in volume terms, water levels are already high in many places and the soil is saturated.\n\nMany residents have no access to drinking water or electricity - or even the means to call for help with telephone and internet services down in many places.\n\nState Governor Eduardo Leite warned earlier this week that the human toll was likely to rise as \"the emergency is continuing to develop\" in the state capital of Porto Alegre and other areas.\n\nOnly two of the six water treatment plants in Porto Alegre - home to about 1.4 million people - were functioning, the mayor's office said on Tuesday, and hospitals and shelters were being supplied by tankers.\n\nBrazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has promised that there would be \"no lack of resources\" to meet the needs of residents.\n\n\"We understand the difficult financial situation faced by Rio Grande do Sul,\" he said at an event in Brasilia, adding he wanted to make sure the state would get \"everything it is entitled to\".\n\n\"We still don't know the exact dimension of the floods, that will only be clear to us when the water levels return to normal,\" Lula said.\n\nAbout 15,000 soldiers, firefighters, police and volunteers were at work across the state to rescue those trapped and transport aid.\n\nThe Brazilian navy also was expected to send its NAM Atlantico vessel - Latin America's largest - to Rio Grande do Sul on Wednesday with two mobile water treatment stations.\n\nIn Gasometro, a part of Porto Alegre popular with tourists, the water continued to rise on Wednesday, complicating rescue efforts.\n\n\"You can only cross on foot or by boat. There is no other way,\" 30-year-old Luan Pas told the AFP news agency next to a street turned into a stagnant, smelly river.\n\nAnother Porto Alegre resident, Adriana Freitas, said she had \"lost {"uri": "8116606613", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "03:59:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T03:59:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T03:59:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.tbsnews.net/world/brazil-floods-leave-150000-homeless-scores-dead-or-missing-845836", "title": "Brazil floods leave 150,000 homeless, scores dead or missing", "body": "Rescuers rushed to evacuate people stranded by devastating floods across the southern Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul on Tuesday, with at least 90 dead, thousands left homeless, and desperate survivors seeking food and basic supplies.\n\nOn the outskirts of Eldorado do Sul, 17 kilometres (10.5 miles) from the state capital of Porto Alegre, many people were sleeping on the roadside and told Reuters they were going hungry. Entire families were leaving on foot, carrying belongings in backpacks and shopping carts.\n\n\"We've been without food for three days and we've only just got this blanket. I'm with people I don't even know, I don't know where my family is,\" said a young man who gave his name as Ricardo Junior.\n\nThe flooding has hampered rescue efforts, with dozens of people still waiting to be evacuated by boat or helicopter from stricken homes. Small boats crisscrossed the flooded town searching for survivors.\n\nThe state's Civil Defense agency said the death toll had risen to 90 with another four deaths being investigated, while 131 people were still unaccounted for and 155,000 homeless.\n\nThe heavy rains that began last week have caused rivers to flood, inundating whole towns and destroying roads and bridges.\n\nRain is forecast to let up on Thursday but then continue through the weekend.\n\nClimate experts attributed the extreme rainfall in Rio Grande do Sul to the confluence of a heatwave caused by this year's El Ni\u00f1o phenomenon, which warms the waters of the Pacific and brings rain to southern Brazil; a weaker cold front with rain and gales coming from the Antarctic; and unusual warmth in the Atlantic also raising humidity.\n\nGlobal warming exacerbates these phenomena and intensifies the effects between such systems, making weather unpredictable, said Marcelo Schneider, a National Meteorology Institute (Inmet) researcher.\n\nELECTRICITY CUTS\n\nIn Porto Alegre, a city of 1.3 million inhabitants, downtown streets were under water after the Guaiba River breached its banks with record water levels.\n\nPorto Alegre residents faced empty supermarket shelves and closed gas stations, with shops rationing sales of mineral water. The city distributed water in trucks to hospitals and shelters.\n\nThe floods have also impacted water and electricity services, with more than 1.4 million affected overall, according to Civil Defense.\n\nAlmost half a million people were without power in Porto Alegre and outlying towns as electricity companies cut off supplies for security reasons in flooded neighbourhoods. National grid operator ONS said five hydroelectric dams and transmission lines were shut down due to the heavy rains.\n\nThe city's airport, its apron under water, has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nFuel shortages were reported as state-run oil company Petrobras said it was having trouble moving diesel from its refinery in badly-flooded Canoas within metropolitan Porto Alegre, a senior government official said.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva said on a government television program that the extent of the damage will not be known until the waters subside. He promised federal aid for the state in what is considered its worst ever climate disaster.\n\nJP Morgan economists projected that the impact of the floods on Brazil's economy would be a modest dent in GDP growth and a marginal increase in inflation, mainly due to higher prices for rice that is largely produced in Rio Grande do Sul. The government said Brazil will import rice to stabilise the market.\n\nBesides destroying critical infrastructure, the heavy rains and flooding have left grain fields under water and killed livestock, interrupting the soy harvest and halting work at multiple meat plants.", "source": {"uri": "tbsnews.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Business Standard"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8116873052", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "07:29:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T07:29:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T07:28:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "http://www.chronicle.lu/category/international-news/49698-brazil-floods-leave-150k-homeless-scores-dead-or-missing", "title": "Brazil Floods Leave 150k Homeless, Scores Dead or Missing", "body": "ELDORADO DO SUL, Brazil (Reuters) - Rescuers rushed to evacuate people stranded by devastating floods across the southern Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul on Tuesday 7 May 2024, with at least 90 dead, thousands left homeless and desperate survivors seeking food and basic supplies.\n\nOn the outskirts of Eldorado do Sul, 17 kilometres from the state capital of Porto Alegre, many people were sleeping on the roadside and told Reuters they were going hungry. Entire families were leaving on foot, carrying belongings in backpacks and shopping carts.\n\n\"We've been without food for three days and we've only just got this blanket. I'm with people I don't even know, I don't know where my family is,\" said a young man who gave his name as Ricardo Junior.\n\nThe flooding has hampered rescue efforts, with dozens of people still waiting to be evacuated by boat or helicopter from stricken homes. Small boats crisscrossed the flooded town searching for survivors.\n\nThe state's Civil Defence agency said the death toll had risen to 90 with another four deaths being investigated, while 131 people were still unaccounted for and 155,000 were homeless.\n\nThe heavy rains that began last week have caused rivers to flood, inundating whole towns and destroying roads and bridges.\n\nRain is forecast to let up on Thursday 9 May 2024 but then continue through the weekend.\n\nClimate experts attributed the extreme rainfall in Rio Grande do Sul to the confluence of a heatwave caused by this year's El Ni\u00f1o phenomenon, which warms the waters of the Pacific and brings rain to southern Brazil; a weaker cold front with rain and gales coming from the Antarctic; and unusual warmth in the Atlantic also raising humidity.\n\nGlobal warming exacerbates these phenomena and intensifies the effects between such systems, making weather unpredictable, said Marcelo Schneider, a National Meteorology Institute (Inmet) researcher.\n\nElectricity cuts\n\nIn Porto Alegre, a city of 1.3 million inhabitants, downtown streets were underwater after the Guaiba River breached its banks with record water levels.\n\nPorto Alegre residents faced empty supermarket shelves and closed gas stations, with shops rationing sales of mineral water. The city distributed water in trucks to hospitals and shelters.\n\nThe floods have also impacted water and electricity services, with more than 1.4 million affected overall, according to Civil Defence.\n\nAlmost half a million people were without power in Porto Alegre and outlying towns as electricity companies cut off supplies for security reasons in flooded neighbourhoods. National grid operator ONS said five hydroelectric dams and transmission lines were shut down due to the heavy rains.\n\nThe city's airport, its apron underwater, has suspended all flights since Friday.\n\nFuel shortages were reported as state-run oil company Petrobras said it was having trouble moving diesel from its refinery in badly flooded Canoas within metropolitan Porto Alegre, a senior government official said.\n\nPresident Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva said on a government television program that the extent of the damage will not be known until the waters subside. He promised federal aid for the state in what is considered its worst-ever climate disaster.\n\nJP Morgan economists projected that the impact of the floods on Brazil's economy would be a modest dent in GDP growth and a marginal increase in inflation, mainly due to higher prices for rice which is largely produced in Rio Grande do Sul. The government said Brazil will import rice to stabilise the market.\n\nBesides destroying critical infrastructure, the heavy rains and flooding have left grain fields under water and killed livestock, interrupting the soy harvest and halting work at multiple meat plants.\n\nThe Rio Grande port, a major port for grain exports, was operating normally, the state's port authority said. However, main access roads were impassable, disrupting grain deliveries to the port as trucks had to make a wide detour, exporters said.", "source": {"uri": "chronicle.lu", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8113981917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "14:40:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T14:40:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T14:39:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/brazil-rain-flood-rio-grande-do-sul-1.7195015", "title": "Heavy rains cause deadly flooding in southern Brazil | CBC News", "body": "Heavy rains battering Brazil's southernmost state of Rio Grande do Sul have killed at least 83 people, authorities said on Monday, while more than 100 were still missing.\n\nThe storms have affected more than two-thirds of the nearly 500 cities in the state, leaving about 122,000 people displaced, according to the state civil defence authority.\n\nFlooding from storms has destroyed roads and bridges in several cities, while triggering landslides and the partial collapse of a dam at a small hydroelectric power plant.\n\nState Governor Eduardo Leite has emphasized that the death toll should still substantially increase as rescue workers gain access to more regions.\n\nRio Grande do Sul's civil defence said 111 people were still missing, a number that has also been increasing in the last few days. On Sunday evening, it had reported at least 78 deaths and 105 missing people.\n\nBrazil's President Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva visited Rio Grande do Sul on Sunday with most of his cabinet and said bureaucracy would not stop the government from reconstructing the state.", "source": {"uri": "cbc.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "label": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Civic Participation", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://i.cbc.ca/1.7195099.1715004712!/fileImage/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/brazil-rains.JPG",
